movie_review_blurb: If many recent art films have made prominent use of nonactors, typically cast as some version of themselves, Pineiro's beguiling, hyperverbal movies revel in the transportive potential -- and sheer pleasure -- of actors acting.

Jackie Chan takes a career swerve with Crime Story, a dark-edged cop thriller in which the star's stunts play second fiddle to plot and mood.
movie_title: Crime Story (Zhong an zu) (New Police Story) (Police Dragon) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Rogue Trader ends up looking simply passe, an '80s yarn in a '90s setting, at a time when money-market characters have long ceased to be heroes for the media or the general public.
Strong playing by topliner Peter Coyote can't compensate for a script that's all over the map and a tone that veers from outre comedy to erotic game-playing.
A quicksilver magical mystery tour through the lives of a bunch of young downtown loners.
A movie that says more about the rebellious Irish psyche than a heap of overtly political pictures.

Though his style and concerns are totally different, there's an almost Rohmer-esque purity and precision about this film, which takes a making-of-a-movie vignette and spins something that's delicate, funny and touching by turns.

The marathon Satan's Tango is a magnum opus to end all magna opera, a dark, funny, apocalyptic allegory of the Hungarian psyche that stimulates, irritates, soothes and startles with blinding strokes of genius in equal turn.
A tony biopic that manages to combine an upfront portrayal of the scribe's gayness with an often moving examination of his broader emotions and artistic ideals.
Delicately rendered, if full of pretty banal sentiments, the film's softer central section is a necessary counterweight to the other two acts, which are largely shot in an oppressive blue filter.
An all-action, helter-skelter, don't-forget-to-buy-the-computer-game ride that makes the two previous installments look like models of classic filmmaking.

With each frame filled to bursting point with visual detail and multiplaned design, plus razor-sharp cutting that often eliminates transitions, it's not a movie you can afford to take your eyes off for a second.
movie_title: The City of Lost Children (La Cité des Enfants Perdus) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Roadside Romeo scores high on the tech front but considerably lower on script smarts.
A clever idea that could have worked as a novella, the urban-fantasy-cum-sci-fier Franklyn doesn't cut it by the bigscreen rulebook.
A good-natured bundle of early-teen femme angst pitched squarely at the youngsters who've made Louise Rennison's books a hit both sides of the Pond.
Anyone expecting the combo of Allen and Albert Hughes and the famed Victorian serial-killer to result in a gritty, stygian, skin-crawling horror movie will be severely disappointed
Strikes too many false notes on the dramatic side to add up to a satisfying emotional experience.
A quizzical dramedy by Kiyoshi Kurosawa that puts some fresh juice into the waning step of the onetime J-horror specialist.
Despite an OK-to-good cast led by Charlize Theron and Kim Basinger, plus a handsome tech package, this remains an elaborate writing exercise with few emotional hooks.

Often gripping at a straight thriller level, but increasingly weakened by its fuzzy psychology, Kathryn Bigelow's The Hurt Locker doesn't bring anything new to the table of grunts-in-the-firing-line movies.
Bergman's script succinctly weaves in refs to themes explored in his own earlier films, notably the destructive force of worship when used as a crutch for human weaknesses.

John Boyne's almost unfilmable novel about a young German kid's-eye view of the Holocaust gets a solid, ultimately powerful translation to the bigscreen in Brit helmer Mark Herman's The Boy in the Striped Pajamas.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Onetime enfant terrible of Polish cinema, and subsequently a wobbly emigre auteur in Belgium, the U.K. and U.S., vet Jerzy Skolimowski makes a small but commanding return to roots in obsessive-love drama Four Nights With Anna.
The '20s-set pic is given considerable bounce by a splendid cast, led by Kirsten Dunst in an eye-opening perf as Marion Davies.
Tale of the struggle for personal freedom in a futuristic, tyrannical society is light on action by contempo standards, and pic's look is uninteresting, apart from occasionally bizarre backgrounds.
The movie raises the bar yet again for South Korean tech expertise and ambition, as well as launching the K-oater subgenre.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Made with a scrupulous attention to the slow-moving realities of grasslands life but lacking in dramatic heft.
Emmanuel Mouret continues his winning streak with Shall We Kiss? another Woody Allen-meets-Eric Rohmer romantic comedy in which the young writer-director again plays the doofus lead.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An extremely rare case of a pic version both written and directed by the book's original author, "The World Unseen" reps a strong argument for leaving screen adaptations to other, more capable hands.
Scott Thomas is aces in the lead role, with flashes of mordant wit that prevent it from becoming a dreary study in self-pity.
Laden with gritty action, but with an emotional undertow that carries the drama even through its weaker moments, pic reps a strong comeback by Hong Kong helmer-producer Peter Chan.

Stripped of Royale's humor, elegance and reinvented old-school stylishness, Quantum has little left except its plot, which is rudimentary and slightly barmy, in the line of the Roger Moore pics of the '70s and '80s.
A well-crafted but in no way earth-shaking entry in the helmer's oeuvre.
Marred by an uninvolving, foggy script that aims to tackle other issues, including postwar loss of faith and hope, and by some eccentric characterizations, notably by Ben Kingsley.

Though recognizably a Leigh movie, with its gallery of Brit eccentrics, Naked dwarfs anything the director has done to date, with a resonant, beautifully modulated script that builds to a bleak but basically optimistic portrait of post-'80s Blighty.
Clunkily directed, gross-out blue-collar comedy is simply a smuttier version of '70s Britcoms like Confessions of a Window Cleaner.
movie_title: The Sex Lives of the Potato Men (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Cool it may be, but scary (or even mildly shudder-inducing) it ain't.
Powerhouse casting, and equally powerhouse direction by Rajkumar Santoshi, makes this an above-average example of mainstream Bollywood thrillers.

Strongest moments are when the pristine HD lensing by Hong Kong's Yu Lik-wai (a Jia regular) and Wang Yu, and warm string music by Yoshihiro Hanno, take over in montages showing the gradual dismantling of the factory.
A neatly observed mood piece about a prepubescent tyke's day on the lam.
3 Idiots takes a while to lay out its game plan but pays off emotionally in its second half.
Pic is largely sustained by the trio's screen chemistry, with Bachchan especially good at the louche comic stuff.
As short on originality and sustained tension as it is long on striking widescreen vistas and impressive technical smarts.
Nicely cast ensembler, centered on a hopelessly disorganized eatery owner and peopled by a weird collection of lovable eccentrics, is pacey entertainment that hardly puts a foot wrong.
Yash Raj's quality-control department seems asleep at the switch in the high-gloss caper-actioner Tashan.
An awesome demo of how to make a pic fly for 2 1/2 hours on technique and star power alone.
This third feature by Dutch helmer-producer Ludi Boeken benefits from his docu background in its realistic, no-frills style and refreshingly unsentimental treatment of the subject.
A pure piece of fluff that's sustained by clever plot twists.
movie_title: Heung joh chow heung yau chow (Turn Left, Turn Right) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Wafer-thin plot is more an excuse for parading a rich selection of character types than anything else, as, refreshingly, the movie never gets tied up in emotional angst or sexual guilt.

Fans of abstract helmer Aleksandr Sokurov will find much to admire in Whispering Pages, a mesmeric journey through 19th-century Russian literary themes that looks like Dostoevsky on acid. Most other auds will head for the exit fast.
Stunningly scored and costumed, and gradually bringing in all the principals as it crosscuts between the Western-influenced party and Anjali's more traditional, middle-class milieu.
A fact-based procedural whose drama gets lost amid its analytical detail.
The Never-ending Story between Arabs and Jews gets another wryly humorous workout, marbled with personal sadness and mystification, in The Time That Remains.
A road movie-cum-gentle comedy of manners that packs an emotional punch in its final reels.

With considerable experience in both comedy and genuine docus, helmer David L. Williams... knows exactly the filmmaking cliches he's spoofing, as well as the deadpan comic timing needed to stretch this over feature length.

This romantic mystery-drama -- centered on an office nerd whose life is transformed by a series of phone calls from, uh, himself -- is thinly plotted, but surfs on the likable chemistry between Akhtar and co-lead Deepika Padukone.
Zinta, who's been carving a growing following the past three years or so, has never been better, definitively moving from juve roles to a charismatic young woman with her sexy, assured Naina.
A full-on local crowd-pleaser, "Blackball" takes the genteel sport of, uh, lawn bowling and comes up with a shameless slice of Brit flag-waving comedy.
For a script that relies more on character-driven than situational comedy, it's the perfs that count, and these are thankfully strong.
Daytime Drinking is proof that a good script and simpatico direction and performances can overcome budgetary restrictions.
An out-there, sometimes wacky, often mystical road movie about a lone Japanese journeyingacross Iceland to perform a family ritual.
An overlong stygian comedy that badly needs a transfusion of genuine inspiration.
This overlong and very Euro-flavored "Spring" won't make many B.O. wickets bloom.
movie_title: Spring Fever (Chun feng chen zui de ye wan) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Recut to a trim 90 minutes, this fragile yarn would work perfectly and have a chance of an afterlife as a specialty item. In its present form, pic may not get much farther than the fest netherworld.
An involving, easily digestible hunk of pure entertainment that could be the trigger for Bollywood's long-awaited crossover to non-ethnic markets.
movie_title: Lagaan: Once Upon a Time in India (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Less visionary than Bong's 2003 serial-killer mystery, "Memories of Murder," but with the same skillfully natural evocation of a rural community hiding dark secrets.
Despite handsome production values and rich, atmospheric lensing by Clint Eastwood regular Tom Stern, this is a heavy meal to digest outside the fest arena.
Too often Karnik's direction is only adequate when it needs to be more shaped for such mercurial material.
A generally entertaining piece of fluff that's kept afloat by a weathered cast including Fabrice Luchini and Roschdy Zem.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A serendipitous marriage of talent in which all hearts seem to beat as one.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Too spotty for non-Indian [audiences].
The film only makes some kind of sense on its own fantastic level.
Assayas' script is more allusive than demonstrative, with a distinct whiff of Eric Rohmer in its conversational blocks separated by fadeouts.
Polanski simply transfers Harris' undistinguished prose direct to the screen and, though the pace picks up marginally in the second half, there's little wow factor in the revelations as they appear.
As in many of Laverty's scripts, problems of overall tone and character development aren't solved by Loach's easygoing direction, though when it works, "Eric" has many incidental pleasures.
Spice World will delight the Fab Five's pre-pubescent fans, recall fond memories of the '60s to those who actually lived through them, and be forgotten within six months.
Scabrous, brutal and hip, Trainspotting is a Clockwork Orange for the '90s.
An unbelievably trashy meltdown of the tartan warrior franchise.
movie_title: Highlander III: The Sorcerer (Highlander: The Final Dimension) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: An ambitious, almost novelistic pic by writer-helmer Lee Chang-dong that ultimately fails to dramatize its lead character's conflicts in cinematic terms.
Lack of dramatic intensity is all the more surprising considering the emotional clout of helmer Marc Evans' two best movies, the chilling Resurrection Man and scarefest My Little Eye.
A feast of A-grade f/x married to a Z-grade, irony-free script.
Fresh, funny and thoroughly engaging.
Classy production values and a textured lead performance by Darshan Jariwala are undercut by a lack of real drama in Gandhi My Father.
A patriotic heartwarmer that scores some old-fashioned entertainment goals despite its flaws.
Though on paper the movie sounds like a slick relationship comedy, it plays much more realistically.
An unashamed tearjerker that's all wrapping and no center.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Three good actors get hijacked by a talky, pointless script.
Rarely has a book sprung so vividly to life, but also worked so enthrallingly in pure movie terms.
Too much caution and too little lust.
Deeply felt but dramatically unconvincing.
Like a tragic overture played at the wrong tempo and slightly off-key, Woody Allen's London-set Cassandra's Dream sends out more mixed signals than an inebriated telegraphist.
Direction lacks the strong hand of To's solo efforts, and pic shows some signs of rush, with abrupt transitions and lack of flow in the editing.
A documentary that's no more than a string of images, Useless is pretty much that.
Basic joke wears off after five minutes, and many bystanders will start to head out of town.
A quietly subversive my-sister-is-turning-into-a-werewolf movie that doesn't wimp out at the end.

The Man From London checks in as good but not great Tarr, more on the level of his first mature work, Damnation (1987), than one to sit at the Olympian table of Satan's Tango and Werckmeister Harmonies.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A slickly packaged college romancer with a mystical component that turns into barnstorming melodrama.
movie_title: Bu neng shuo de. mi mi (Secret) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The point at which a good director crosses the career bridge to become a substantial international talent is vividly clear in The Edge of Heaven, an utterly assured, profoundly moving fifth feature by Fatih Akin.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Whether one responds or not to the pic's (certainly valid) theme... pic has a deadening lack of dramatic development and a plethora of thinly drawn characters.
Strongly cast tale of royal scheming, family skeletons and healthy slaughter is an involving mood piece.
Yam's easy charm holds the pic together, and supports are are all solid, with Lam standing out among the sparrows and the Mandarin-speaking Lin fine as the skittish but crafty Chun-lei.

Both the pic's power and its problems stem from Love deliberately taking no moral position nor offering any solutions; he gives his audience what it wants at a gut level and doesn't wimp out at the end.
A finely tooled Brit-lit costumer that, like Anne Hathaway's flawless accent as the young Austen, lacks only that final convincing 5%.
Reps an accomplished debut by writer-thesps Sacha Tarter and Trevor Sather, with closely knitted direction by multihyphenate Richard Bracewell.
Pic's film-buffy slant, with a finale at the Cannes Film Festival, won't mean much to the ankle-biting segment of Bean's audience.

German writer-director Christian Petzold returns to top form in Yella, another precision-helmed, tightly wound, metaphysical thriller that confirms him as one of Germany's finest middle-generation directors.
Tip-top performances, led by young British thesp Jamie Bell, and a deftly handled tone reflecting all the title teen's confused emotions make Hallam Foe a viewing delight.
An entertaining, deliciously played walk-and-talker by helmer-writer-star Julie Delpy and co-star Adam Goldberg.
Like a collapsing star, Sunshine initially burns brightly but finally implodes into a dramatic black hole.
For viewers prepared to go with the flow, it works at a gut, movie-movie level.
Summer '04 more than confirms the promise of young Teuton helmer Stefan Krohmer.
It's clear from the start this isn't a revenge drama that's going to wimp out at the end.
A hypnotic portrait of village life -- largely through the eyes of three youngsters -- that packs a poetic-spiritual punch way beyond its placid surface.
A full-bore zombie romp that more than delivers the genre goods.
A typically quirky chamber drama by helmer Kim Ki-duk.

A seriocomic crimer by Tsui Hark, Ringo Lam and Johnnie To that's a diverting, sometimes head-scratching experiment that will mostly chime with Asian movie buffs rather than satisfy general auds as a single, homogenous pic.

Appears to have also lost its script in transit. Pointless exercise in search for identity is a big step back by Lebanese-born filmer Danielle Arbid after her flawed but promising first feature, In the Battlefields.

Six years after the 7-1/2-hour Satan's Tango, Magyar maverick Bela Tarr makes a stunning feature return with "Werckmeister Harmonies," another hypnotic meditation on popular demagogy and mental manipulation that's a snap at 145 minutes.
More rooted in small-screen sitcom than anything deeper.

Robert Redford's first helming chore in seven years, and his most directly political pic yet, amounts to a giant cry of "Americans, get engaged!" wrapped in a star-heavy discourse that uses a lot of words to say nothing new.
Delivers solid, brainless entertainment thanks to a precision-built script and performances that are all in the same key.

The long-running antipathy of Greeks toward Albanian migrants -- generally depicted as criminals or hijackers in movies -- finds a much more solid dramatic base in The Homecoming, a notable first feature by writer-director Vasilis Douvlis.

Diaz is largely performing in a vacuum: Keitel, unbelievable for starters as a middle-aged judge, seems unsure at which pitch to play the largely physical comedy, and Sheffer, as the best friend, is fairly vanilla.
Seductively lensed but emotionally uninvolving.
movie_title: Farewell My Concubine (Ba wang bie ji) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: One of the freshest mainstream Hindi pics of the year.
The movie has a visual poetry that's refreshing.
Pretentious dialogue is matched by equally uninvolving performances in this debut feature by Sande Zeig.
Young English actress Kate Winslet adds luster and energy to Jude, a bold and generally successful attempt to adapt Thomas Hardy's final novel, Jude the Obscure, to the bigscreen.
The heart of Pushkin's celebrated classic pumps firm and full in debuting director Martha Fiennes' richly textured pic version.
A small picture with a big heart.
Smooth-flowing direction, a shrewdly pruned script and a top-flight ensemble cast that visibly relishes both the dialogue and one another's perfs make this a tony item for upscale, mature audiences.

Balances character, grit, spectacle and visceral action in a meaty, dramatically satisfying pie that delivers on the hype and will surprise many who felt the Hong Kong helmer progressively lost his mojo during his long years stateside.
A luscious labor of love.
Richard Harris is at his weariest, battle-scarred best...
Looking more like the fourth or fifth entry in a franchise than only the second, cell phone horror pic One Missed Call 2 manages to ring up a few genuine scares and a neat final twist.
A movie that keeps jumping the gate and finally unravels all over the floor.

As the film progresses, it becomes painfully clear there's no real point to the story; what we're witnessing is a cool, intellectual exercise, as devoid of character and motivation as the two psychos themselves.
Though it's a half-hour too long, the result is an insightful, ironic portrait of campaigning at street level.
Witty, playful, romantic, tragic, Park Chan-wook's I'm a Cyborg, but That's OK is a whole chocolate box of emotions in a highly decorative but absolutely characteristic wrapping.
movie_title: I'm a Cyborg, But That's OK (Saibogujiman kwenchana) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Though it doesn't quite match recent classics like Kabhi khushi kabhie gham in sheer technique and production sheen, in-depth star casting and thorough entertainment values make this a must-see for Bollywatchers.
Widescreen package is technically slick at all levels, and ditto the action choreography, in a cartoonish way.

More realist than his debut feature, Atlas (All the Weight of the World), but much more thinly plotted, Thanos Anastopoulos' sophomore outing, Correction, spends a long time going nowhere in particular.
Saawariya entices, fitfully springs to life but finally outstays its welcome by a good half-hour.
A lighter but also more emotionally satisfying take on the lives of favela gangstas.
So resolutely caring -- and devoid of real drama and interesting characters -- that it should have "approved by the Dyslexia Assn." stamped on the posters.
As an undemanding slice of masala entertainment, it's more than worthy of the Yash Raj quality stamp.
Lacking any really sharp dialogue, the film just about goes the distance by juggling its characters in short, sketch-like scenes and inserting occasional musical montages.
A good-looking but slim confection that's short on the multi-characterisation and sense of entwined destinies that mark the great Lelouch sagas.
An involving, highly accessible portrait of an emotional menage a quatre in the modern-day Chinese capital.
Film is largely just the sum of its images and, aside from a surprise ending, is more a pleasant view with charming moments than a consistently gripping narrative.

Bertolucci and co-writer Clare Peploe seem intent on deconstructing the story's interesting elements at every turn, substituting woolliness for clarity, atmospherics for real emotion and an often condescending, armchair-liberal naivete for real political
Has a wow factor unequalled by any Hindi film in memory.
Very Korean in its emotional content, while also preserving a quizzical distance that is quite French, pic is one of his lightest and most easily digestible metaphysical meals to date.
A sexy, good-looking political bodice-ripper with an almost flawless cast at the top of its game.
A long-limbed story that is utterly simple in structure, but decorated with enough character interplay and side plots to keep the movie ticking over to a powerful finale.
A kaleidoscopic but engrossing study of the shifting sands of friendship among a group of Parisians.

Casting and playing are uniformly tops, with special praise for Fionnuala Murphy as Kellegher's best pal, Ruth McCabe as the quiet, long-suffering mom, and the five kids as her loopy brothers and sisters.
An entertaining blend of genre elements and spiritual content that plays much better than it sounds on paper.
A genial, feel-good item.
Paul Schrader's 1985 biopic necessarily guts his controversial life - but the visual style is superb.
movie_title: Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)

movie_review_blurb: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee proves that The Ballad of Jack and Rose was no fluke and that Miller can produce work just as good as the best of recent American independent cinema.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is musical history that deserves to be placed alongside the best of its era.
Jones, as writer and director, has fashioned a good-looking, claustrophobic piece despite his limited resources.
Everything about the film looks and feels authentic, from the desolate landscape dotted with trailers and fast-food joints to the people who populate a borderland that offers none of them much hope.

Jordan gives all this an entirely appropriate sheen and the cast play well through glazed eyes. The film will fascinate those who love to see the tormented lives of those who seem luckier than the rest of us.
Well-acted but increasingly either melodramatic or just plain dull.
You could hardly call this a timely film but it does remind us of the evils of racism and the misery it causes.
I have never been quite sure why this $30 million comedy made by John Landis in 1980 became such a cult.
It's melodrama, and sometimes absurdist. But there's a sense of humour too and while it trips over itself in the effort to be original, it is an impressive piece of film-making all the same.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sergio Leone's 1969 masterwork, in which he pulls together most of the themes of his three Dollar films, and also contributes one of the most famous credit sequences in history, will wet your lips all over again.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: Fumihiko Sori's attempt to make an original addition to the Zatoichi martial arts franchise never reaches the virtuosity of Takeshi Kitano's original. Needless to say, the fight scenes are better than the dialogue.
Nowhere near the originality of anything from Pixar.
Tony Scott's remake of the semi-classic of 1974 begins and ends badly.
This turns out to be another bad choice for Bullock who, without playing badly, sinks in the general morass.
Painful in the extreme, showing how even the best actor can be made uncomfortable by clumsy direction.
Much demented laughter and lavish screams of terror decorate José Mojica Marins's outré Brazilian horror.
movie_title: Encarnação do Demônio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A more complex, beautiful film than one had dared to hope. I'll never giggle at yodelling again.
This is an above par effort, excellently played and just naughty enough to be thought daring as well as amusingly spiteful.
It is tightly constructed and successfully portrays the underlying tension between Edinburgh's newly prosperous and those who never had anything and never will.
The numerous battle scenes, culminating in the famous Battle of Red Cliff, prove Woo is an action director par excellence.
It mostly maintains an artful minimalism you will either find subtle or terminally boring.
Spectacular and totally meaningless, like a video game transposed to the big screen and worked by a maniacal enthusiast.
Though there's not much of a story, the animation is expert and imaginative.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is not made for anyone with more than a sprinkling of intelligence.
The plot is total rubbish, and no amount of slick film-making can make you believe it is worth all the blood and gore we have to sit through.
Its subject now reveals itself as political and social freedom in Castro's Cuba and this is what makes it an intelligent companion piece to Memories of Underdevelopment, Alea's earlier film.
Wit occasionally gets a look-in but it isn't often, while Black's ebullient over-playing and Cera's nervy wimpishness make a partnership that often seems about to make you laugh.
My Sister's Keeper becomes a well-heeled weepie in which the family's comfortable existence, despite the misfortunes of fate, is hardly challenged at all.
Cuaron's mixture of near farce and realism works well most of the time, though there are moments when the narration suffers from too many meaningless metaphors.
The smallest detail is given due weight, and we feel we begin to know these people. The cast seldom puts a foot wrong. Denis has never made a more resonant film.
The film may not be a masterpiece but it is tender, truthful and acted with great sensitivity.
There's not enough about the conflicts between Paul and those who controlled his records but this is a fan-like yet not too oleaginous tribute.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's not clear whether the director, Brad Silberling, is camping it up or simply trying to get through it all without too much strain.
What a comforting fable to warm us as the evenings draw in. Away with cynicism! Enjoy if you can. The cast look as if they did.
The film's innate sense of humour and the naïve poetry of its making, which admittedly sometimes descends into whimsy, provide a resolutely optimistic feel.

Working to a spare screenplay, Bahrani offers none of the usual clues about either the cabbie's surprising determination to prevent the tragedy or the old man's reasons for suicide. This doesn't always help the quiet drama.
Both stars seem bemused in their parts and it is left to Martin Sheen and a pet parrot to emote. The parrot, in fact, is the best thing here.
Inspiration is pretty fallow after about half an hour.
The debutant director is done no favours by a screenplay from Vince Vaughn and Jon Favreau which gives him little to play with and them few chances to shine as actors.
An original take on genre movies of its kind.
Park is clearly an exceptional director capable of being weirdly funny, quirkily fantastical, brutal and sexy, sometimes at one and the same time. There's no one quite like him.
The whole film is smart cinema. I wouldn't be surprised if Smith didn't land up with a contract in Hollywood.
The film can never quite make up its mind whether it's about the circus or the vampires and ends up a mess of its own making.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Glasson's film is well-shot and directed, and more than decently acted. As a genre movie, it suffices.
One would imagine, and hope, that an Oscar nomination beckons.
They look as if they could provide more laughs but are defeated by bovine gags retrieved from a trashcan full of out-takes.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film has an immediate power no one could deny.
You could say that this is one step up from the ghastly Lesbian Vampire Killers, since it suggests they are getting what they deserve from the other sex. But that step is a short one.
To revisit it now is still to marvel at its wit, audacity and sheer entertainment value.
While I'm sure that truth is indeed even stranger than this fiction, there is little here to drum that fact home with conviction. Dr Strangelove it is not, by a very long way.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like a folk tale crossed with a thriller and road movie. Without a doubt it is one of the best new British films of the year, if you can justly call it fully British.
Mad, Sad & Bad, it must be said, is not made with any great flair. But Luthra extracts good performances from his cast and his writing gives them something to do once the story gets going.
After watching this, you'll probably end up worrying as much as they do.
It is a tragic story that deserves to be remembered and has rarely been told on film.
It's noisy, fast-paced and stuffed with special effects. The screenplay? You've got to be joking!
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It remains totally watchable and, in Cassel, it has an actor as strong as anyone.
It has atmosphere and tension, and the performances are far better than usual for this sort of caper.
The ugly truth about this insipid romcom is that Katherine Heigl and Gerard Butler are entirely wasted.
This is often a very funny film, made more relevant by a recession which began after the film was made. Michael Moore should watch out - he has competition.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Two good performances, some expert cinematography from Florian Ballhaus and an air of intensity that keeps you gripped.
The aliens look like cast-offs from a bad Spielberg film and the whole family are boring examples of Hollywood's ordinary Americans.
The characterisations are just a little unorthodox and the whole thing, despite a soggy middle during which nothing much happens, goes with an above average swing.
There's a lot of blood and little logic but the actors scream nicely.
The result is uncommonly pleasing or defiantly twee: take your choice.
movie_title: The Young Girls of Rochefort (Les Demoiselles de Rochefort) (1968)

Worth seeing if you are a fan of the director, but for anyone else I'd suggest first seeking out his more famous films of the 1950s and '60s.
So modest, unassuming, and in touch with the way human beings interact with one another that it's almost impossible not to appreciate or enjoy.
'It's unfortunate that what should be an emotionally-engaging film is so completely unaffecting'
'shows the consequences of what we have done in the past and the danger of where we are heading'
Socially aware, but so nihilistic and fatalistic that it's irrelevant since it is unwilling to push towards the social change that the prior films supported so adamently.
Howard Hawks and Cary Grant made several famous films together but it's a shame this one is often overlooked since it's a true comic gem that works well on every level.
movie_title: I Was a Male War Bride (1949)

movie_review_blurb: A fun-filled adventure story that is certain to keep kids on the edge of their seats while teaching them important life lessons.
It works both as a philosophical treatise on politics and film as well as an entertaining and often amusing look at a future overrun by technology.
'The satire is sharp, the comedy is witty and urbane, and the characters are so full of life it feels as if they might just walk off the screen.'
'Characters are brought together through ludicrous connections that are so unbelievable, it makes it difficult to laugh at even the few jokes that are funny.'
Quote not available.
Writer/ director Aleksandr Sokurov has made a film that is unique and so visionary that it is impossible not to applaud his efforts, whether you like the film or not.
A great little film that, while lacking visual flair, portrays a faith in and understanding of mankind that is difficult to find anywhere these days.
It may not be Luis Bunuel's best film, but this is probably his most complete statement on sexual relations and the dark side of desire.
For fans of Hitchcock, it will be obvious that this isn't one of his best, but, as always, the atmosphere of suspense and mystery that he creates makes the film worth seeing.
It is impossible to be unmoved by both the beauty of artist Andy Goldsworthy's work and his undying commitment to it.
movie_title: Rivers and Tides: Andy Goldsworthy Working With Time (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Avoids formulas, instead opting to take the audience down the same windy, confusing roads that the characters travel.
In his own unique style, Federico Fellini has created a beautiful work of art that is as amusing as it is inspiring.
As a low-budget first film, director Peter Weir could've done worse, but I'm thankful that his career continued in a very different direction than this film would suggest.
Takes an equally harsh look at the dark side of comedy, society's value of success driving people to desperate acts, and the press' bloodthirsty desire to sensationalize.
F.W. Murnau's visual style adds depth and excitement to the drama, and humour.
movie_title: Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans (1927)

movie_review_blurb: Co-writer/ director Catherine Hardwicke has a talent for bringing emotion to the screen, but she must learn to channel it toward a deeper understanding of the characters.
An amazing mood piece that captures the characters' inner turmoil, confusion, restlessness and the strange, surreal surroundings that are the cause for their discord.
'A vivid and dazzling depiction of the Cuban landscape and culture but also a weak plot that barely supports the intricate, detailed visuals.'
'A humanistic piece about how the Holocaust, fascism, and the Second World War left permanent emotional scars on everyone who lived through it.'
'Rather than allowing us to digest the story as it actually happened, the filmmakers seem to be deadset on making sure we reach the same conclusions as they did.'
'What makes Honeybee so bad is its inability to get past the clichés and say something interesting.'
'Although it is set in the past, its universal themes of love, war, and man's struggle to understand his place in the world are as relevant today as they've ever been.'
movie_title: Ningen no joken I (The Human Condition I) (No Greater Love) (1959)

movie_review_blurb: In the '90s we had Seinfeld; in the '50s they had I Love Lucy.

Human Capital treads similar structural and thematic ground as Crash and Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's first three films, coming away with some of the advantages of the latter films and the weaknesses of all.
There's a good deal to be excited for in Ain't Them Bodies Saints; with another couple films under his belt, hopefully Lowery can develop a more unique voice and make a Badlands of his very own.
Palacios deftly navigates the landscape, seamlessly switching tones, moods and paces, rendering Gueros a film full of rich emotions, raw settings, and a unique portrait of youth in rebellion.
The skillful handling of such radical yet delicate material in the film's final act is quite a sight to see.
Tabu is strange, powerfully evocative, playfully experimental, and truly one of the most beautiful films in recent years.
Walking Out is modest in scope, its concerns limited to man's attempts to live both morally and harmoniously with nature.
Hahaha continues down this path with, as the title clearly suggests, an extremely funny, yet still sobering bend.

Oki's Movie is not without its charm and all three characters themselves being film directors explicitly aids its thematic concern with the struggle between the ways we represent ourselves and the ways we truly behave.
Immature simple-mindedness renders all of the film's dark undertones null and void, and as such, there is rarely a moment that doesn't come off as exceedingly phony or forced.
While it effectively sticks the knife into upper-class mores, it certainly has a been-there, done-that feel to it that the former does not.
Kon-Tiki sinks itself well before its journey is finished.

Leaving his traditionally bifurcated structures behind, Apitchatpong Weerasethakul plunges even further into the realm of tropical surrealism, tapping into parallel realities and past lives with a delicate restraint that is all his own.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Kitano's deft handling of violence, both in its effect on the viewer and as a commentary on the twisted code of the yakuza, is more than enough to keep Outrage fascinating to the very end.

Jacques Tati, perhaps the greatest of comic directors, made films that demand to be seen on the big screen - his use of space, framing, and perspective require such a scope to truly appreciate the near-obsessive attention to the smallest of details.
I have to swallow my pride here and say that JLG lost me with Film Socialism.
With Poetry, Lee Chang-dong once again gets a brilliant performance out of his female lead, this time from Jeong-hee Yoon.
Unfortunately the make-up on DiCaprio and Armie Hammer's elder J. Edgar and Clyde was distractingly awful, so in the end, I guess the dress-up feel to the film couldn't be avoided.
To forever be remembered as the notorious "USB stick film," Jafar Panahi's This Is Not a Film is first and foremost a revolutionary act against a repressive regime.
The ying-yang approach, remarkably different from any other interpretation of the source I've seen, is equally invigorating and frustrating, but in the best way.

Kiarostami adopts a lush visual scheme and almost lighthearted tone that provides levity to a remarkably demanding work, one that's as playfully deceptive and cunning as anything the director has made before.
Like Father, Like Son explores the meaning of parenthood in a most unique way, taking a deeply thoughtful approach to a hypothetical and following its unknown paths in an organic manner.

The film's successful balance of focusing on Eno as musician and songwriter and Eno as innovator, collaborator, and soundshaper helps to reveal a man whose role seemingly changed with each subsequent album.
movie_title: Brian Eno: 1971-1977 - The Man Who Fell to Earth (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The directness of Sun-nam's voiceover encapsulates what's salient about Hong's approach, which lays everything bare and leaves little room for ambiguity.
The film's emotional resonance feels hollow, watered down by an overstuffed plot that bites off more than it can chew.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It remains too uncompromisingly black and white as a character study and a story of the conflicts of faith.
6 Days boils down the intricate relationship between Iran and the West into a tense standoff of conflicting ideals where the values and perspectives of only one side really matter.
The Hitman's Bodyguard sometimes just appears to be parodying the sort of mess it ends up being.
England Is Mine is a tour ride through a legend's formative years that's more concerned with the familiar signposts than the intricacies of the scenery along the way.
Bob Roberts is a shrewdly drawn portrait of the unsettling intersection of entertainment, business, and politics.
Fernando Guzzoni's Jesus is at its best when it steers clear of pat moralizing and simply yokes its moody sense of atmosphere to the aimlessness of the story's young characters.
The film was clearly conceived and written by men who have no interest in approaching female friendships with any degree of complexity, curiosity, or respect.
Despite The Good Catholic's interesting macro approach compared to other films of its ilk, it's far less successful on a micro level.
Edoardo de Angelis's coming-of-age portrait is poignant when fixated on the intricacies of a complicated sisterhood.
It's impossible to take it seriously as anything other than an Abercrombie & Fitch ad posing as a political thriller.
Stronger's embrace of the unpredictable nature of Jeff and Erin's journey yields an array of raw, surprising character beats that flow organically from one to the next.
Mark Felt is a kind of hagiography, and it leans toward whitewashing its subject's legacy.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Goodbye Christopher Robin is often bathetic, but its most glaring faults lie in its extreme structural imbalance.
Sleepless Nights Stories merely lingers on the personal, and the mundanity that was so magical in one film is now rendered just plain ordinary and dull.
Ultimately, what is a worthy premise is squandered, as the delineation between fact and fiction is never satisfactorily examined.
Despite its sci-fi premise and air of apocalyptic doom, Melancholia, surprisingly enough, is a small film, locating both its terror and its humor.

While it's not among Tarr's greatest works, this self-proclaimed final film could not be a more fitting conclusion to a great career, in its strict adherence to both his formal and thematic tendencies.
The Day He Arrives is a minor effort from Hong, but it's also rather humorous and, like his other films, contains a brilliantly constructed narrative that continually turns back on itself.

Unfortunately, Oslo, August 31 is more of a step sideways than anything else, taking the easy way out with a drug-addiction narrative that helps Trier circumvent any major risks and thus preventing him from reaping any major rewards.
The results are emotionally ingratiating and quite touching.
Beginning with the sound of gunshots as paint splatters on a canvas, Hélène Cattet and Bruno Forzan announce their intent to elevate style above all else.
movie_title: Let the Corpses Tan (Laissez bronzer les cadavres!) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As the film proceeds, Ildikó Enyedi incessantly explicates the subtext of the characters' developing connection.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Hannah plays out in long wordless takes often stripped of context and attains a discomfiting intimacy in its chilly examination of a woman coming undone.
It bounces from one topic to the next with the carelessness of someone flipping through a book and reading from a random page.
Like Loïe Fuller's serpentine dance, the film is structured on repetition: spinning and spinning but never actually taking us nowhere.
The film is unable to reconcile a desire to ridicule its own artifice with constant attempts to foster genuine empathy and dramatic tension.
The Greatest Showman's spectacle is overshadowed by its archaic and misguided notions of American exceptionalism.
A welter of dissonant intentions, the film fails to seamlessly intertwine its elements of realism and fantasy.
In attempting to grapple with issues of bullying, mental health, burgeoning sexuality, and pedophilia, the film bites off more than it can chew.
Bethany Ashton Wolf's Forever My Girl is less reminiscent of a country song than of Radiohead's "True Love Waits."
Den of Thieves displays a reverence for the taut and moody tension-building tactics of Heat, but it's unable to bring emotional resonance to its action sequences.
The will-they-won't-they of the film is a non-starter, and as such the film's climax is stripped of suspense and even the most basic of dramatic payoffs.
Lin Oeding's Braven thrives on both the beauty of its natural, snowbound surroundings and the brutal instincts of man.
Danny Baron's film awkwardly melds Bollywood romcom tropes with a half-hearted critique of the GMO industry.
Ben doesn't deserve our sympathy, in part for how noxiously the film has imagined the female characters who surround him.
There's no follow-through or follow-up on how the main character's voyeurism informs his burgeoning sexual perversions.
Sadly, for a film at least partially about the impact of evening news and political coverage, little importance is given to the actual political content as compared to the results.
Its characters feel genuine and lived-in, each with a good heart at their core yet molded into more aggressive, abrasive people by an environment that's unforgiving in its cruelty and indifference.
movie_title: Life and Nothing More (La Vida y Nada Más) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Kidnap is an efficient vehicle for the delivery of some lean action that's frequently weakened by a scarcely whip-smart script.
Matthew Porterfield's film ultimately conveys the limitations of freedom within towns like the one at its center.
Initially offbeat, Bitch awkwardly pivots toward a more inspirational story of regret and reconciliation.
Attenberg doesn't have a sense of true purpose and cohesion.

A surprisingly pedestrian film from the usually engaging and inventive Lynne Ramsay, We Need to Talk About Kevin feels more like an early film by an American indie filmmaker looking for his/her big break.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The pure terror of rural mundaneness and geographical remoteness turning savage and deadly is ultimately the most stirring and chilling notion presented by Snowtown.
A Separation ends on the perfect note, a nearly impossible decision whose weight is left on our shoulders while the credits roll.
If given the chance, this is not to be missed on the big screen.

Faith, the second film in the Paradise trilogy, may not be as effective as its predecessor, but its story of a recently converted fundamental Christian woman and her now-handicapped Muslim husband returning after a two-year absence is still quite good.
What the film lacks in Haneke's usually impressive formal rigor, it makes up for with truly earned emotional truths.
While the film doesn't have the complex ambiguity and thematic richness of its predecessor, it is a charming and unique addition to the Kiarostami canon.
The film is an easily digestible replica of the truth, bathed in honeyed cinematography and sentimentalized adulation.
Even overlooking its fictionalized account of an inexplicable political resurgence, the film falters in its needlessly convoluted plotting.
Joseph Kosinski's Only the Brave displays a kinship to Howard Hawks's hard-nosed, old-fashioned pragmatism.
The longer things drag out, All I See Is You becomes every bit as amorphous as its protagonist's vision.
The performances and narrative flounder to strike the right balance between comedy and drama.
The film is admirably frank in its depiction of lingering trauma but too often struggles to capture its more ineffable qualities.
Gilbert exposes a wealth of unsuspected pain and tenderness beneath Gottfried's often thorny exterior.

The pressures of Christmas prove too great to fight off and the need for feel-good holiday cheer inevitably veers the film toward half-hearted, sentimental drama that seems purely obligatory to its seasonal milieu.
Like so many shoot-'em-up video games that repeatedly break for cutscenes, the film too often diffuses its tense energy by whipping up context.
Big Sonia is structured in a way that bumps the tragic and demoralizing up against the comic and inspirational.
The film is lazily content to simply put its female characters through the potty-mouthed, gross-out comedy ringer.
Although Last Rampage's overarching narrative travels a well-tread road, it strikes a number of potent grace notes along the way.
The Last Face's shameful exploitation of Africans doesn't stop with the mere privileging of its two wealthy white doctors and their trivial personal struggles within the narrative.
Imagine Carl Theodor Dreyer, with a dash of Herzog, directing a surreal 50s Technicolor western and you might have some idea of what to expect from Lisandro Alonso's baffling yet transfixing Jauja.
It's a challenging film, but it rewards with a fully realized historical context, multifaceted characterizations, and profound philosophical and political realizations.
movie_title: Mula sa kung ano ang noon (From What Is Before) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Leviathan does drag at times, particularly in its hefty middle section, but the powerful symbolism of the gut-punching finale makes it worth the wait, even it makes you lose even more hope in humanity.

Desplechin is so manic, he can't help but explore other avenues, both comic and dramatic, that give My Golden Days an organic, lived-in feel that defies the trajectory of the typical coming-of-age film.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Shot in crisp black-and-white with minimalist sets, In the Shadow of Women is able to concisely say in just over an hour what most romantic comedies today fight to say in over two.
The film is usually transparent in its unbridled and excessive adulation of Al Gore.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Tside from a handful of stunning shots, the film often drags while its new ways of approaching the text fail to bring anything new to the table.
The climb itself is a masterful feat of physical acting and comic timing, surpassed only by the best works of Chaplin and Keaton.

While Hitchcock/Truffaut the book remains a far more insightful examination of Hitchcock's style, the film offers more than enough entertaining inside stories and critical analysis of his films to recommend to any fan of the master's work.
Ultimately, it's a pretty good film, but perhaps Audiard's weakest to date.

None of its individual parts seems particularly impressive on paper, yet Haynes taps into the hyperspecificities of a forbidden, secret love to such an achingly tender degree that I feared Mara's character would literally shatter into pieces.

The Forbidden Room is an absolutely manic, joyous romp through a hilariously warped revision of seemingly the entirety of silent film, an endlessly inventive celebration of the limitlessness and sheer dexterity of cinema from the first frame to the last.
Porumboiu's film is meticulously paced yet utterly lifeless, delaying the inevitable merely because he can, yet even the twists at the end are neither intellectually nor cinematically engaging.

There is no attempt to set Sands up as a great martyr, no Jesus pose or sentimental music to manipulate emotions. Hunger is interested in none of this. Instead, [McQueen] lets the bodies that sacrificed themselves tell the story they created.
Hong embraces the power of fiction both to reflect reality and to reflect upon itself, and, in doing so, once again shows why he's one of the most important directors working today.

Ultimately, what In Jackson Heights left me with is a powerful sense of hope -- hope that in the midst of these troubling times..., a community like Jackson Heights exists, and has existed for some time, in peace.
The horror clichés could practically write themselves from that point, but Eggers himself resists temptation at nearly every turn.
hile it shares a similar atmospheric style, pacing and pathos as his other films, it may be [Assayas'] most complex and rewarding one to date.

As weak as Valley of Love is for much of its first hour, its final act, where the two characters are confronted with the reality of their son's request and Gerard's revelation about his own personal health, is at least more palatable.
It's certainly not a bad film, but aside from Spall's performance and the cinematography, this is one of [Leigh's] lesser works.
The humans battle the kaiju both intellectually and physically, although it doesn't take long to realize that Pacific Rim is really only concerned with the latter.
It is in within these acutely observed aspects of humanity, not at its best or worst but simply as it is that Two Days, One Night achieves its greatness.
The Hunt has left me more shaken than any other film I've seen all year.
[Lilting] wears its heart on its sleeve, but without bleeding too much, and is overly square and precise, but also a welcome reprieve from the irony-prone fair that most often fills our cinemas.
A film that effectively examines both the familial conflicts in Japan's transitioning society and the wondrous avenues each individual within the family explores.
It has a levity and self-aware absurdity that makes it not only a different kind of beast, but also another film that marks Ben Wheatley as a young director to keep an eye on.
An equally frustrating and rewarding experience.
If I seem overly harsh towards a film that I'm essentially recommending, it's only because I expect more from the director.

As frustratingly inconsistent as The Family Jams can be, fans of freak folk will likely find just enough rare footage to make it worth their while, but everyone else would be wise to sit this one out.
Unless you're jonesing for new Japanese animation, you'd be advised to reverse your gravitational pull and steer clear of this one.

Although Wild Grass doesn't reach the heights of Resnais' earliest works, it provides ample evidence that the director can still produce vibrant and thrilling work and hopefully will continue to do so through his 90s as well.
Ultimately, Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Süss is interesting for plunging into the labyrinthine psychological turmoil of the Harlan family, but it focuses too little on the root cause.
movie_title: Harlan - Im Schatten von Jud Süss (Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Seuss) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I am in favor of films remaining enigmatic or having an air of mystery about them, but Cherry Blossoms crosses the line into aimlessness.
Frustrating and fascinating.
I don't begrudge Boogie Woogie's attacks on the art scene for its pretension, greed, and self-aggrandizement run rampant; I begrudge the fact that the film is guilty of these very same things.
Costa strikes at the core of what makes these people tick and the tragedy of their being ignored and abandoned by the government and general population.

While the film's minimalist nature is its greatest asset in the first act, it ultimately makes its flaws and screenwriterly touches all the more apparent, resulting in some great individual slice-of-life sequences and some truly hackneyed ones.
Like most of Denis's work, Bastards provides no clear conclusions and her characters' behavior remains just as ineffable, endlessly complex, and unknowable as human behavior in real life.

[The film's] uncanny ability to be meticulously precise in some aspects, yet distant and mysterious in others make it a unique achievement and exactly the kind of film that could only be made by a master like Hou Hsaio-hsien.
As tough as it is to sit through at times, it's worth the effort to get to the beautiful nuggets of gold it occasionally mines.

As expected with Lanthimos, The Lobster is utterly bizarre... it's the director's first film in English, yet also his first to show shades of human side, even as it concludes that we humans are an exceptionally silly and sad little species.

Using clips mostly from obscure, silent, and often explicit films, along with quotes by Plato, Hesiod, and Sappho, Deutsch constructs his own unique history of love, lust, desire, and violence on the silver screen.
movie_title: FILM IST. a girl & a gun (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Unwittingly perhaps, Sand Castle reveals itself as a microcosm of America's foreign policy in the Middle East.
In none of its manifestations is grief as tidy and meticulously arranged as in Eric D. Howell's film.
The main character is too often pushed to the sidelines so that the filmmakers can indulge tired family-drama tropes.

Throughout, Jim Jarmusch playfully blurs the line between driver/passenger, servant/customer, and native/immigrant.

Its gory conclusion is presented with an ostentatious grandiosity that the rest of the film simply doesn't justify.

Like Lisa and Kate's pendular swings between hope and despair, Johannes Roberts's film can't help alternating between the genuinely terrifying and the just plain dumb.

movie_review_blurb: If nothing else, it introduces Anna Rose Holmer to the world as another bright young female director with a unique perspective and, especially for a debut feature, a surprisingly impressive command of pacing and tone.
One of the year's more delightfully offbeat and pleasurable films.
If you're a fan of the topic, it's at least mildly entertaining, but it rarely feels like anything more than a glorified DVD extra feature.

My Happy Family casually lays out the domestic space where the story's events takes place with acutely detailed cultural specificity.

While the meandering story is coherently told, it labours under a dual storyline that tells completely different stories until they're tied together fairly unconvincingly at the end.

Much of the cast is stiff or just plain bad.
If you can get past the taboo subject matter, it will be well worth your time.
An intelligent, funny look at dating and relationships among the middle-aged.
Spirited Away is one of the most richly imaginative and visually spectacular films you will see this year.

A wonderful, wholesome and, best of all, intelligent piece of entertainment that will appeal to all ages.

movie_review_blurb: Features such an uncanny ear for dialogue, characterization and situations that it seems almost like a documentary.
