Treadaway may be sympathetic and charming as the struggling musician, but this is Bob's show, all the way.
Bayona packs his tale with spellbinding visuals and honest emotion, and if the ending doesn't reduce you to tears, you may be the real monster.
Leonard sticks much closer to his wife's original goofy plot, and the result is a bland story that never really commits to what it wants to be.
Hart's exuberance make him a captivating performer-and his energetic delivery helps even the most mediocre jokes land.
The standout performances belong to Will Smith, who gets the balance between a dreaded killer and a caring father just right. Margot Robbie too is a hoot as Harley Quinn.
What this movie lacks is self-belief and great music. If the whole point of the film was to make it a tribute to Michael Jackson then MJ's original tunes should have been used.
Andy Serkis for another thundering performance. If you thought he was good as Gollum in the Lord of the Rings films, then his superlative performance here will just blow your mind away.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Mummy films starring Brendan Fraser were campy fun. Here, it's another ball game altogether.
Watch it for its mindblowing imagery.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: All-in-all, Bareilly Ki Barfi is a good second film from Ashwiny Iyer Tiwari and gives her a chance to prove her versatility. Watch the film for some good, clean fun.
We just wish that more brainstorming should have gone into turning one of the iconic works on fantasy into film.
All-in-all, while Mubarakan suffers from a strained and predictable plot, its silliness does makes you laugh. So go watch the film if indulging in there hours of escapist comedy is your game...
The setting is achingly real. You feel you're looking into the life of any other yuppie couple.
Today, when fundamentalism is one the rise, we need more films like Dharam Sankat Mein to remind us that harmony and tolerance are the need of the hour.
The film is a complete disservice to Mustafa, who looks like a romantic hero but made to act like a heartless killer, something which doesn't suit him at all.
The film has a Rashomon like narrative, putting different viewpoints and storylines in place and whetting your appetite with each reveal.
The film would have fallen flat if not for the efforts of Reynolds and Jackson.
Chimbu Deven had the right idea but lost his way in execution. We hope he learns from his mistakes and makes a better film the next time around.
Bullett Raja is director Tigmanshu Dhulia's most commercial film as yet -- and his weakest.
Watch the film if you like cornball comedies. It's a pure massy, masala entertainer that's good to go on a lazy weekend.

The original creator Bob Kane, who was given the task of creating a real world superhero to counter Superman, would have been immensely proud of this film. Because this is as real as it gets... and then some.
[A] heart-warming tale about passion, friendship and forgiveness.
Vikram shines in every frame of the film.
The film hooks you from first shot onwards and refuses to let go. The suspense is maintained throughout. There are enough red herrings to keep a convention of Agatha Christie fans happy.
The cliches work because of the phenomenon called Salman Khan.
The script would have looked good on paper but didn't translate well into celluloid.
Court is another reminder that we need drastic changes in the way our judiciary functions; it raises relevant questions but doesn't provide answers.
Margarita With A Straw is a film with its heart in the right place. However, it tries to be too many things at once, which results in its undoing.
The best part of the film is the awkward relationship between Krish and his overbearing, abusive, alcoholic father, played superbly by Ronit Roy.
So should one watch this almost three-hour long non-mystery? Yes, if you are a Sunny Leone fan.
Thanks to some superlative acting, you forget how thin the plot is and immerse yourself in the lives of the characters.
It's Kangana's film from frame one. The way she flits from one aspect of her character to another without breaking stride shows her maturity as an actor.
You enjoy watching Taapsee Pannu despite the unconvincing storyline and the glaring plot holes and that's her real victory.
Director Drew Goddard has made a clever film. He has shown us the elements of classic horror, told us what we miss in today's films and questioned the need for watching the genre.
You feel Himesh [Reshammiya's] goal for himself in the film was not to let any flicker of emotion escape his visage.
A little more attention to the plot would have turned it into a far better product than it is right now.
All-in-all, the film is a genuine attempt at a family entertainer and would surely make you smile throughout.

This is Star Wars for adults. Well-loved characters die, the violence is gory by and large and the atmosphere is more on the lines of the French Resistance during World War II than the light-hearted thrillers that George Lucas films were.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Christian Bale has given another fine performance...The film's cinematography captures both the West's harshness and it's beauty.
Shot in blue and green hues, the emotionally charged film is a visual feast.
It all looks mightily fine on paper but the idea to celluloid transition has been a drag.

Coogler has played with the age of dilemma of winning freedom through armed struggle versus gaining it through peaceful means. But Black Panther is no Gandhi, he's a superhero with enhanced abilities and a combat suit that James Bond would kill for.
It's the performances and not the screenplay that keeps our interest alive in the film.
The film would have been lacklustre if not for Hugh Jackman, who has given his heart and soul to the project.
All-in-all, despite the PG-13 rating, the rebooted version of Jumanji remains a fun-family film to watch over the year-end holidays.
It's seldom that we make introspective films laced with dark humour. It's great to find such superlative effort from first time filmmaker.
Kapil Sharma tries hard to carry the film on his shoulders but mostly flounders. You keep waiting for him to take command of the screen but that never happens.
Summing up, Thank You For Your Service is a fine debut for Jason Hall. Let's hope he continues his fine form in future endeavours as well...
American films often are accused of either making a caricature of the minorities or of dumbing down their culture, their traditions. Coco thankfully escapes both allegations.
The film's deft pace, it's frenzied silliness, punchy wisecracks coupled with the Johnson and Hart's deft handling of the situational comedy holds your interests despite the threadbare plot.
Director Andrew Haigh slowly builds a sense of unease between the couples.

There was enough potential for his character to have evolved into something truly magnificent but the chance was let slip by the director. And that, sadly, is by and large true for the whole film itself...
Vikram Bhatt has made an unintentionally funny film. He perhaps needs to go back to the drawing board before he takes up horror as a subject once more.
All-in-all, Inferno doesn't have that edge-of-the-seat quality that was necessary for an end of the world scenario film.
The Accountant is an out-and -out action film and action film buffs won't be disappointed by the use of heavy duty guns and armour piercing bullets which turn the climax into a veritable battlefield.
The cracks show up in the not-so-young smile...
All-in-all, Dongri Ka Raja can be labelled as an honest effort to recreate the gangster genre. A little more effort would have resulted in a far better film.
Lara [Dutta] is a hoot as she deadpans her lines, showing flair for campy comedy.
Navnet Kaur Dhillon looks cute and carries off her role well, as do Tisca Chopra as the over caring elder sister and Sachin Khedekar as Pooja's dad.
[Mishra] Sikander is a hoot actually in his role, swinging from a WASP with a Manhattan twang to an NRI filmmaker with a yen for melodrama.
movie_title: Tere Bin Laden: Dead or Alive (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kumud Mishra's portrayal of a sympathetic civil servant is praiseworthy, as is Prakash Belawadi's as a disgruntled middle class man who can't adjust himself to the situation.
Go watch this short, sensitive film that gives out the message that parenthood has nothing to do with one's sexuality. That all every family needs is a little more love to make the scars heal
All-in-all, Phobia makes for an engaging weekend watch. It isn't high on gore but will still thrill all the same...
Jha, who has written the film, ends up giving the better role to himself and surprisingly carries it off too.
Freaky Ali is a sweet little comedy that's sure to put a smile on your lips.
All-in-all, Kahaani 2 is a good watch. But it isn't as riveting as the Kahaani.
[Tiger Shroff is] choosing his films wisely, making sure he plays to his strengths.
The actors involved try their hardest to rise above the material given to them.
Kaurismäki's unworldly drollery ... feels like it's from another time-until it's ruptured by the shocking contemporaneity of the global refugee crisis against which the movie is set.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A Spielberg-Nolan lovechild of sorts, wondrous and mind-bending in equal parts, Denis Villeneuve's latest is a quintessential science-fiction blockbuster steeped in genre traditions and made singular by Amy Adams's transporting performance.

For all its bluntness, The Insult confronts us with the true complexity of the Middle Eastern conflict and the ways in which war obliterates the ideas of victimhood and responsibility, rendering the justice system farcically inadequate.

Smart and thoughtful while never sacrificing tension, excitement or teeth-shattering action... Peter Berg has made a current events thriller that will stand in the years to come as a cinematic snapshot of our f***ed up moment in time.
The Invasion is a wretched mess from start to finish, and it taints the reputations of every single person who not only appears in it, but also goes to see it.
Superbad, essentially, is the filthiest episode of Freaks & Geeks ever.
You need to see Hot Rod just so you can say you were on the Danny McBride bandwagon a year early.
[T]he antidote to bloated, stupid threequels and mindless junk food cinema. Bourne isn't just the best action movie of the summer, it's one of the best movies of the year.

David Yates and screenwriter Michael Goldenberg have successfully pared the unwieldy book down into something that works well enough that this film places third in my personal best of Potter movies list.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps the scariest thing about Joshua was the feeling I got at the end that I had just sat through some kind of weird gay panic movie.

Transformers is probably the Rosetta Stone of Bay's career. All of his favorite elements are here: military fetishism, vehicular fetishism, hot chick fetishism, explosion fetishism, sweaty machismo and a brutal disregard for an interesting story.
Live Free or Die Hard is like the anti-Die Hard, a big, dumb cartoon that makes Bad Boys II seem restrained and realistic.
I was scared, I was creeped out and I was grossed out... Hostel Part II is damn unsettling.
Soderbergh and company have said this is the last Ocean's film, and it should be - they finally got it right. Anything that comes after will only tarnish the cocktail hour perfection of this movie.
Gracie is a rousing sports film that ultimately earns that lump in your throat.
Bekmambetov mostly keeps his story moving forward on the back of his immensely likable protagonist, played by Konstantin Khabensky.
[Mr. Brooks] piles subplot upon subplot, making what should have been a taut, disturbing thriller feel bloated and aimless.
Bug is a movie intent on getting under skin in much the same way its protagonists think insects have gotten under theirs; it's a movie that gnaws on you long after you've walked out of the theater.
Paprika is yet another incoherent anime that's more interested in its warmed over visuals than in indulging in any kind of storytelling or character work.
Our news media is letting us down and killing us with frivolity; thank God Michael Winterbottom is there trying to take up the slack.
Halloween is, objectively speaking and without thinking about the original, a crummy film. As a remake of the Carpenter movie it's a heinous abortion.
American Zombie is hands-down the best film I've seen so far this year.

Projected in digital format with booming, all-encompassing sound, Blade Runner: The Final Cut is a marvel of technology and dedication. As a film it's still the same dead-eyed pretty girl who looks good on your arm but is a real bore over dinner.

Watching Keith Richards paraded around like a man in a character costume at Disneyland I found myself realizing how f***ing lame this group has become... This isn't rock and roll - this is a very loud Lawrence Welk performance.
Angel-A is one of the most gorgeous movies I have ever despised.
Proves that there's still lots of humor and insight to be found in the walking dead.
If The Bank Job is forever known as 'The One Where Statham Cold Cocks an Old Dude,' the film's already a wild success
Rambo earns the Red Badge of Carnage.
The monster mayhem is impressive in scale and presentation... makes a moribund genre like the monster movie suddenly come roaring to life.

[The film] is, in the end, mildly disappointing, a movie that is beautiful but without warmth. Hopefully Joe Wright can continue on the visual path he is blazing for himself while not again losing the humanity of his wonderful Pride & Prejudice.
A very middle of the road film, one that will never get your heart racing or piss you off too much.
A consistently great experience, and I'd love to go back and see it again in three weeks when the Hot Topic generation has latched on to it and will be singing along in the theater.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Southland Tales is a monumentally bad film, a landmark in 21st century cinematic awfulness. There's no real meaning to be found here; it's all signifiers for half baked ideas that Richard Kelly never managed to turn into anything worthwhile.
Beowulf is an exhilarating experience, a glorious spectacle and a film that rewards viewers who keep their brains turned on behind their 3D glasses.
[A] turd covered in tasty Ghirardelli chocolate - as soon as you sink your teeth in you know you've got mouthful of sweetened sh*t.
The worst and most seriously disappointing of all the Dead movies.The whole premise is botched... badly [and] the audience continuously and rudely gets yanked from the experience of the movie.
This is a movie with its heart in the right place, which is beating and bloody in somebody's hand.
Anderson's strength - he's a consummate visual stylist, a natural born scene maker - is also his weakness, in that he favors obvious constructions, representations and meanings in his scripts.
There's nothing sadder than a prestige picture that just doesn't work, because these kinds of films so rarely allow themselves to have fun.
Chris Weitz dropped out of the film years ago because he thought he couldn't do this story justice. Turns out he was right; as a director he's competent but doesn't have 'sweeping epic' in him.
The finale ends up going on so long that by the time the 'important' events occur at the end I couldn't find it within myself to care anymore. I had been swashed, buckled and CGIed into apathy.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie, in many ways, is Agatha Christie getting triumphantly butt****ed by Michael Bay. With jokes. And more than a dash of genius.

28 Weeks Later starts strong, but it quickly disavows any potential it may have had as a dramatic piece and veers directly into inanity, eschewing character, tension or plot for a chase scene that lasts for maybe 45 minutes.
The Good Sheperd feels like it escaped from a parallel world that never experienced the one-two punch of Jaws and Star Wars and instead based its blockbuster formula on The Godfathers.
The Good German is an easy movie to admire... but within all that style there's nothing to love. It's a hollow movie.
By reducing the story of homelessness to only Chris Gardner's, The Pursuit of Happyness is saying that anybody can get out of the gutter by simply really, really wanting to do better.
A motion picture that isn't just bad, it's abysmal. One of the worst films of the year, and nothing but a disservice to everyone fighting in Iraq (and to everyone sitting through the movie).
"And I Am Telling You..." is going to go down in history as one of cinema's great musical moments... and it's without doubt one of the most electric and amazing moments of 2006.
Passable but not really memorable, it's a movie that should have been released over the summer, which still reigns as the best time of year to see a guy get killed with frog-poisoned darts.
Nothing more than chicken soup for international humanitarian crises, an opportunity for Hollywood types to decry the bloody stone trade while reaching for a little Oscar gold.
We Are Marshall is the most insidious kind of bad movie - the very well made kind.
For the first time ever, James Bond is tough, smart, sexy, smooth, witty... and sort of three-dimensional. Welcome to the 21st century, Mr. Bond.
Really - a montage of characters reaching emotional breaking points and having cathartic meltdowns, set to Year of the Cat? F*** you.
Itchy and Scratchy and Houdini
Clint creates a fascinating topography of hell here, and the amphibious landing is unrelenting... but the treacle is just as unrelenting, and takes up more screentime.
A movie that fits perfectly in the Terry Gilliam oeuvre, except for the fact that it is a dismal, rank bore that so misses the thematic mark that it becomes a complete nightmare.
David Lynch has been working on his latest film, Inland Empire for years, and it feels like he has included every minute of the footage he shot.
When the Dawn of the Dead remake features a better chainsaw kill than your film with the words "chainsaw" and "massacre" in the title you know you've made a stinker.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As much as I appreciate the films he has made over the last decade, there is no denying that The Departed is Scorsese's best film since Goodfellas. It's just a f***ing awesome movie.
Sacha Baron Cohen is a master improviser.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I guarantee to you that this film will, in a few years, be regarded as a small classic. Discover Once now.

Grimly beautiful - Eastwood's images are as stark as the black and rocky beaches of Iwo Jima itself. But grim is really the operative word for this movie; it's relentlessly grim, almost to the point where it gets redundant and ponderous.

Children of Men is about a miracle. Children of Men is, itself, a miracle. It's a movie that can single-handedly remove the scales of cynicism from your eyes, reminding you of what wonders cinema is capable.
Disturbia isn't your first choice this weekend if you're in your 20s or older, but for the crowd who are about the same age as Shia and the gang, this is great Friday night material.
The movie never quite clicks because it insists on telling two stories - one that is dramatic and one that slowly peters out, neither of which complement each other.
If George W Bush could prove that Saddam Hussein had funded this movie I would reverse my stance on the Iraq War and say that every single civilian casualty was justified.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Everything that GI Jesus wants to talk about is worth discussing [but] sadly the third act hits the movie like a torpedo, sending it slowly sinking into failure.
Verhoeven has finally come to a place where he can perfectly balance his populist, lowbrow impulses with his desire to say something important.

Death Proof is, in many ways, an amazing approximation of the old exploitation films, but with an unmistakable QT vibe. Rodriguez, on the other hand, directs his half as the fever dream of someone who has only been told about exploitation movies.
The movie works despite its well-designed but boringly realized bad guy, a real testament to the well-defined, decently written characters of the Turtles themselves.
Rocky Balboa WORKS.
The Last Mimzy, directed by New Line head honcho Bob Shaye, is very obviously aiming square at the ET target, which wouldn't be bad if Shaye had a clue what made ET work.
Director Zack Snyder is a visual genius - of that I'm sure - and 300 is very much a movie John Milius could love.
Zodiac feels a lot like a masterpiece... [it's] like quicksand, inexorably drawing you deeper and deeper into itself.

They could have saved time and money and simply given paying customers cards reading, 'You have a small penis,' or 'Those pants make you look fat.' Surely that's an easier and more cost effective way to insult the audience.
Ghost Rider is very much a movie for 9 year olds that feels like it was made by a 9 year old. Even 14 or 15 year olds will feel too old for what passes as cool or dark in this edge-of-camp movie.
A restrained and respectable look at what might be the single least interesting aspect of a stunning true story.
The best superhero movie since Spider-Man 2. Robert Downey Jr is the film's best special effect.

"Why is this day different from all others?" is a question every Jewish family hears at the Passover seder. "Why is this biopic different from all others?" is a question that no one seems to hear in Hollywood.
Filled with real characters, great pop culture references, foul-mouthed jokes and with a gooey sweetness right at the center, Knocked Up is a comedy classic.
A fantasy film without much magic but plenty of darkness and violence.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gutsy and big-hearted.
Hellboy II feels like nothing less than the successor to Pan's Labyrinth... dressed in spandex.
A capable, intelligent, compelling thriller, but it seems possible that [Crowe and Affleck's] shared scenes were shot at different times and digitally composited together.
Here's the big mystery of Pittsburgh: How did this movie manage to be so completely terrible?
Perfect; it's dark and strange and dances right on the edge of being completely mean and unfriendly, but manages to keep from tumbling over. It's f***ing amazing.
A feel-good film of rockin' proportions.
An amazing work of dark, dark genius.
Perhaps the only use this film has is to give philosophers who sit through it some way of experiencing what eternity truly means.
A note to all indie filmmakers (one that will be too late for Matt Aselton, writer (with Adam Nagata) and director of GIGANTIC): quirky is a tone, not a plot.
You know those movies that look like they're going to be really insipid and then completely surprise you? 17 Again isn't one of those.
MONSTERS VS ALIENS comes so close to being something truly special, but even as a movie that's just enjoyably above average it beats the pants off everything else that Dreamworks has done so far.

It's not bad. It's often really funny. But it's almost completely ephemeral; there's barely a story in the film, just a concept geared towards getting Rudd and Segel hanging out onscreen for 90 or so minutes.
Morally hollow, devoid of bigger issues and discussion points.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Inside Man is the Spike Lee film for people who don't go to see Spike Lee films, and it's also a fun treat for people who see everything the man does.
Frame for frame, The Incredibles is as good as any live action superhero film ever made, and often far more convincing.
Here, shorn of every ounce of body fat, Bale is laid open like an autopsy specimen, and he easily gives his best performance.
Between Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban and Lemony Snicket 2004 is a banner year for dark and fun kid's films.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I would never do what Christopher McCandless did, and yet I found Into the Wild to be incredibly inspiring.
ADVENTURELAND is loving towards its characters but also brutally honest about them. sweet and funny and real, and definitely one of the best coming of age movies in years, if not ever.
The Unborn is, like its main character, at war with itself. Neither side wins.
FIGHTING may find an audience on home video, where the flaws become easier to tune out and the things that are good - and that are, on occasion, legitimately great - are easier to focus on.
JJ Abrams is a miracle worker. He has taken a script that is so bad and so dumb as to be almost a disaster and made a movie that's a lot of fun and actually quite good from it.
Grace is a truly horrifying movie.
Cute and touching, and more than a little romantic. It's the kind of movie that will find its audience, and its audience will adore it.
Admirable and enjoyable and beautiful, but it's a movie for the littlest of the little ones.
If I was 10 years old, GI Joe would be one of the best movies I had ever seen. As a grown up it's one of the better summer movies; a delightfully light, fun and action-packed kick in the ass.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkable achievement... moving, funny, honest and true and sad and sweet. A movie about characters who we have come to know and love, and a movie that understands that it's these characters, and not the magic they perform, that is the real hook.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While Public Enemies is a well made, well acted, well written film, it's one without a spark at the center to make it truly special.
Revenge of the Fallen is almost literally plotless. It's like a movie based on a TV Guide description. A bloated, ponderous piece of s**t.

To quote Spinal Tap, 'It's such a fine line between stupid and clever.' Wolverine rarely threatens to cross that line into clever, instead remaining fairly stupid, mostly formless and endlessly silly.
Year One is so dedicated to being historically accurate that it only uses jokes that are at least two thousand years old.
Under all the layers of MTV circa 2003 there's a tight, good story that's been barely changed from the original, and there are some good performances trying to poke their way through the ADD editing.
Drag Me To Hell isn't a perfect movie, but it may be a perfect moviegoing experience.
From start to finish Up is simply amazing.
Maybe those lowered expectations played some part, but I was very, very surprised by the actual movie.
McG has sparked a moribund franchise back to life, giving fans the post-apocalyptic action they've been craving since they first saw a metal foot crush a human skull two decades ago.

Much easier to sit through than the stultifying THE DAVINCI CODE. In fact, the pace could almost be considered breakneck, especially for a movie where someone is always stopping to deliver a lecture on history, art or symbology.
Rudo Y Cursi is charming and fun, but never slight.
If only Hollywood was willing to make more science fiction films like this one.
While it has lulls and sleepy moments, Undertow also full of startling truths and beauties, as well as offering a window into a side of the country that movies rarely bother to look at.
Not only a fun heist movie but also a moving tale of spiritual uplift and beauty.
Street Fight isn't going to restore your faith in our desperately broken electoral system, but Cory Booker -- and the last moments of the movie -- may help you harbor that little flame of hope.
Bong has worked a tonal miracle here - he's made a movie that elicits laughs, groans, screams and winces yet never lets one upstage the others.
A patchwork of good scenes that are stitched together, like a feature film made from a diverting YouTube series, but as a film it's... nothing.
Burn After Reading is the new Coen Bros classic that you'll be quoting ad nauseum for the next decade.
With Brick Rian Johnson got me excited with his storyteller's tools; with The Brothers Bloom he used them to transport me. I loved being the mark in this con.
A series of really wonderful kills that kept me highly entertained and a gay love story that could be the best since Brokeback Mountain.
As a piece of agitprop op-ed filmmaking, Religulous is often brilliant. It's definitely hilarious, sometimes to the point of leaving me wheezing and giggling.
Alex Aja has not only made the worst film of his career in Mirrors, he's made possibly the worst film of the year.
The only title that works for this movie is Three Days of the Mongoloid.
The only enjoyment I got from the film was laughing at how miserable it was and then zoning out during the boring fight scenes... which make up, no joke, about 90% of the total running time.
The aesthetic here isn't homaging 80s buddy action movies so much as just making one. It's MIDNIGHT RUN for the 21st century.
Make no mistake, it's bad. But it's fun bad.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The greatest X-File of all may be solving what paranormal phenomenon convinced Fox to greenlight this piece of crap.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Someone get the Batman a lozenge.
Wall*E begins as a truly groundbreaking work and then turns into just another diverting cartoon with some wonderful themes.
The Incredible Hulk is often loud, and it can be quite dumb, but it's certainly not bloated.

Sometimes you want to listen to a symphony, sometimes you want to listen to a beautifully crafted pop song. But sometimes you want to crank the speakers and bang your head, and that's why God (and Timur Bekmambetov) gave you Wanted.

I laughed loud and hard throughout this film, and I enjoyed every minute of it and have no problem enthusiastically recommending it to you. But time and again the movie's jokes reach for comedic nirvana and fall just ever so short.
A fine movie and a fascinating near miss. Even a Spike Lee film as imperfect as this one is more deserving of your attention than 90 percent of what's out there.
Van Damme puts his best work ever on screen, but ironically the guy who never relied on a good script before is let down by one here.
Despite being rushed so it could be released before the election, and even with all of its faults and problems, W. remains a very good movie, and is often funny and surprisingly sympathetic.
I urge you to go see this film when it comes to a theater near you -- not only to enjoy a well made film, but also to send a message that there ain't nothing wrong with a little bump and grind.
The film is a mishmash of half-baked jokes, sitcom scenarios and Owen Wilson attempting to float by on his charm.
To me Blade Trinity deftly dances at the edge of "So bad it's good" territory, staying just on the side of being good.

A huge budgeted superhero movie that delivers intellectually? That takes serious, ballsy chances with the form? Why, that sounds like a piece of art. A glorious, epic, exciting, mind blowing piece of art.
The franchise needed this. A 21st century FRIDAY THE 13th with the best Jason ever.
Guaranteed to send everyone out of the theater with red eyes and wet cheeks. To its credit, Marley & Me achieves that with a maximum amount of class and a minimum amount of manipulation.
Benjamin Button may be the most passive titular character in a motion picture until The Terri Schiavo Story gets off the ground.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: VALKYRIE feels like the exciting second part of a miniseries. Part one had all the character bits and drama, though.
An in-your-face bit of bloody fun that's guaranteed to thrill those looking for a gory good time.
I hate myself for sitting through the entire film.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's not often that I get to trot out this little critical bon mot, but here goes: Punisher: War Zone kicks ass.
Dark Shadows at Degrassi Jr. High, but with half the budget of either of those two shows.
Anyone who does not cry during Dear Zachary: A Letter To A Son About His Father is inhuman.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: More often than not Zack & Miri will elicit genuine laughs. And it has a lot of heart to go with those laughs.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

While the action is more muscular and more exciting, the biggest villain Bond has to face this time out is his script.
Dull, predictable, ugly, filled with bad or lackluster performances, contains objectionable racial material and just generally lacking in anything worthwhile. One of the worst movies of the year.

If you want to get prepared for this one, don't go back and watch the other Indy movies. Pull out The Lost World instead. Both films are directed by the same Steven Spielberg - bored, only mildly engaged and seemingly going through the motions.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Little Children is bursting with fantastic performances, filled with great and often hilarious dialogue, structured with layer upon layer of resonant meaning and shot with gorgeous, masterful camerawork. The film works on every single level.
If I hadn't known that World Trade Center was an Oliver Stone movie, I never would have guessed it; in fact I might have ventured Ron Howard as the man behind the camera.
Mirren gives one of the finest performances of the year.
Murray has been playing this role - the sad clown, the bitter and aloof lonely man - for a decade now.
Burt Reynolds fired his agent after Boogie Nights. If he has a lick of sense in his head, he'll kill his agent after Dukes of Hazzard.
This is a funny movie. I'm going to go so far as to say this is one of the funniest movies. Ever.
I don't want to say that the film is a sham, although I suspect that it may be...
Van Sant has made a film just short of a minor masterpiece.
If 8 Mile was Rocky, Hustle & Flow is Raging Bull.
I have a soft spot for movies that are this sick and twisted, and Rejects is the real thing
Grizzly Man is by turns hilarious, scary, touching, beautiful, bizarre, fascinating and always thought and argument provoking.
Praise the Lord, Vince Vaughn is back.
Murderball isn't just one of the year's best documentaries, it's one of the year's best movies period.
Excruciating and less scary than a clogged up toilet, Dark Water should be allowed to quietly drain.
Cronicas is two thirds of a really good movie - someone let me know when they find the rest.
Fantastic Four is a movie that could have been a lot better - but it could also have been a lot worse.
War of the Worlds is, hands down, the best big budget film of the summer. Maybe the year. Spielberg has crafted a real classic.
Missing any kind of magic at all, Bewitched should be burned at the stake.
I didn't think Romero could come back at this late stage of the game and redefine the whole genre - but he does.
Charlie is [Tim Burton's] best work in a decade...
Decades from now Howl's Moving Castle will be looked back at as a classic.
[A]n electrifying testament to the unstoppable power of the individual to make a difference.
Sure, it's a fairly broad sex comedy, but it's a sweet one.
This movie is a classic already - you'll be quoting it and referencing it as soon as you have walked out of the theater.
Shopgirl gets the ultimate stigma: It's a smart, small film that's perfect for adults.
I recommend Doom with a lot of hesitation.
[I]f you're open to the experience, Elizabethtown is one of the sweetest, funniest and better films of the year.
It manages to be surprisingly entertaining for a golf movie, but otherwise it has nothing new going on.
I struggled mightily to stay awake through large stretches of Mirrormask.
Capote is always kept aloft by the amazing performance at its center.
Adults will be bored and irritated by this thin film.
Folks looking for just a sci-fi film will be wonderfully surprised by Whedon's whip crack dialogue and hardcore fans will be just happy to see these people back.
A weird, beautifully made, stirringly acted movie. But also a frustrating movie that feels like a very artfully written but poorly thought out high schooler's blog harangue.
Sure to please the legions of kids who have bought every Jack Skellington item at their local Hot Topic.
Quite simply, Everything is Illuminated is a wonderful film, a moving film, and a funny film.

"[A] perfect example of rote Hollywood fare being produced in a different language."

movie_review_blurb: [O]ffers us a glimpse at a future where one of our most idiosyncratic directors has been beaten down by the corporate system. Now that's the making of a Terry Gilliam movie.
SFMV is a cinematic tour de force, if an unrelentingly cruel one.
It's got plenty of talented people working on it, but it seems like they all turned a blind eye to the fact that they were creating something truly terrible.
The movie slowly moves away from being an engaging film about people and starts to fit itself into the mold of every other dumb action movie you've ever seen.
A nasty, mean, unrelenting movie. I loved it.
I walked out of Dogtown almost bouncing...it's a rush, a kinetic spectacle that puts you right back into your own 16 year old shoes...
Samara, the evil ghost from The Ring, hasn't upgraded.
Ice Princess is pretty decent as a schlocky tween empowerment movie...
Mail Order Wife is astonishingly cruel, and I say that in a good way.
I like films that are paced slowly, but this movie passes by in geological ages.
I've only seen this sensitive but slyly subversive film once, and I am dying to see it again. Danny Boyle's Millions is a modern classic.
This past week the 1500th American died in Iraq, making the documentary Gunner Palace all too timely.
The Jacket's not a failure, and I'm sure that it will have its fans. It's not a movie I ever need to see again, though.
Melinda and Melinda is a treat for Woody Allen fans. For one thing, it's pretty good, which has been a rarity in the 21st century for the director.
I'm not sure if it's surprising that the film is almost uniformly awful.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: I defy anyone to see this film in a crowded theater and not get caught up in the energy and the excitement.

Gorgeous and engaging, The Aviator is the director's greatest achievement since Goodfellas.

Boring and tepid, it's something best forgotten about. Which you will do within an hour of seeing it.
[A] good first effort, a lyrical little movie that is filled with a relaxed Southern charm and a beautiful regard for the people - real and fictional - who inhabit it.
[I]n no way a great movie, [it's] a serviceable take on the property that manages to be both appallingly liberal with and nicely faithful to the character.

One of the things that makes this film much better than it has any right to be is the enormous talent of Bernie Mac.
The Ballad of Jack and Rose is an often engrossing character piece, filled with small moments of beauty and sadness.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Weirdly faithful to the original... but often feels like a child imitating an adult - it gets the motions right, but it never understands any of the meaning.
Unfortunately the comedy here is never as sophisticated as in Pixar films.

movie_review_blurb: Crash mercilessly apes Magnolia.

Often wry but rarely witty, the film never feels like anything but a pleasantry.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Lex Luthor would have been right at home in Enron.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: I don't know how comfortable I am proclaiming this, but 2005 could be the year known for the rehabilitation of Ashton Kutcher.
If I really had to break Save the Green Planet down I would say that it's Carpenter's They Live by way of Scorsese's King of Comedy.
Duchovny has crafted a small but not slight film about some impressive truths, filled with some wonderful characters and only slightly overbaked.

One part comedy, one part thriller, Kontroll is a film that's tough to pin down but easy to like.
Darkly funny and aggressively transgressive, Oldboy is the kind of film that sends you out of the theater dazed...
Niki Caro is one of the brightest and best directors working.

The Legend of Zorro passes corny right by and goes for silly, and stupid, and boring.
A bittersweet little film.
[Clark] completely squandered this scenario and these kids.
[R]eminded me of one of [John] Ford's more elegiac Westerns
All I wanted was a magical remote control of my own so I could skip past seeing this unfunny and monotonous piece of crap.
Watching The Outsider is like mainlining pure movie love.
Cars runs out of gas long before it reaches the finish line. With twenty minutes cut it could have been a contender, but it's the worst Pixar film to date.
This version of The Omen brings virtually nothing new, and instead shabbily pantomimes through the script of the original.
The single best action movie of 2006.

In one of the most exasperating recent examples of directorial overindulgence, what had been a fun film starts wearing out its welcome, leaving audiences with twenty minutes to slog through after the movie feels like it already ended.

I wish that there was a way to get the facts in this film in front of the audience that needs to see it, the audience that takes the words of human mockeries like Michael Crichton and Michelle Malkin as gospel.
Retarded, ridiculous and crushingly dull.
With Dead Man's Shoes I can get the thrill of a guy in a gasmask taking an axe to a bastard, while also getting interesting characters and moral complications.
By the end of Poseidon the eponymous cruise ship lies on the bottom of the ocean, and so, I hope, does the reputation of director Wolfgang Petersen.
It's almost fascinating to watch Art School Confidential slowly start coming apart before it finally crashes and burns.
A wonderful throwback to 70s era filmmaking... Norton reminds us that he's a serious contender for the title of our greatest modern actor.
This is a movie that is already slipping out of my mind and will probably never be revisited - or even thought about - again.
What if they threw a satire and no jokes came? This is the question American Dreamz answers in its interminable running time.
Last Stand offers fans some astonishing pleasures... but also many stings of opportunities lost.
It's the second act where Hard Candy earns the seat-squirmer reputation it will one day have.
[P]acks as many thrills and as much fun into thirty minutes as any of the Indiana Jones films did into their entire running times.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: You won't have seen anything this funny in a theater since... well, maybe since Anchorman.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A truly powerful, moving and insightful look at the confusing cusp of adulthood and the scars it leaves you with.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Forest Whitaker gives a masterpiece of a performance, the kind of incredible acting that crosses the line into just being.
Feast is a genuinely fun splatter movie that almost never lets up and definitely never takes itself too seriously, going into Evil Dead territory.
It's hard to dislike the film's earnestness.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This movie has upped the ante so much that I think the only way a third can top it is to intentionally cripple or kill one of the guys.
[G]lum piece of nonsense.
De Palma's Black Dahlia captures exactly what I see in my head when I read James Ellroy's novels.
The Fountain is beautiful, gripping and utterly transcendent. It's the best film of 2006.
A filmmaker blossoming into true greatness... Pan's Labyrinth is a film of breathtaking emotional, thematic and visual depth.
The Protector is a disaster, barely made viewable by Tony Jaa's incredible physical abilities, often trapped inside sh***y fight choreography anyway.
[S]uffers from a bad case of narrative kryptonite, leading the story to a dead end conclusion that feels less like a finish and more like the production ran out of film.
Holy psychosexual issues, LaBute-Man!
Lassie wears thin. It's a little too long, and by the end the tugs on your heartstrings feel more like heartstring muggings.
The movie they warned us the video game generation would make.
An After School Special done up in gritty indie style.

An amazing movie, one that will sweep you up emotionally and intellectually, that will give you plenty to think over and even more to marvel at. It's an achievement that needs to be seen to be believed, and once it's seen it's guaranteed to be beloved.
[A] complete hagiography, a film that smoothes out every rough edge in Lennon's life to the point where he's made into someone who seems terribly uninteresting and naïve.

I can't tell if the movie means to leave us somewhat hopeful or utterly devastated by the way God treats his own geniuses.
A flattened jumble.
Wolf Creek is an unrelenting, grueling experience.
What does a masterpiece look like? Like The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada, one of the best movies of the decade so far.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Marebito feels like it's twice as long as it should be. It feels like an episode of a horror anthology show, stuffed to make it feature length.

Jackson again reminds us that he's a genius.

Syriana is a dense, layered film that is essentially this season's broccoli %u2013 it's good for you, and when prepared right (as Gaghan has), tasty.
These films just keep getting better and better.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's indulgent, and more than once it's patently unbelievable, but Jordan knows how to make a movie, and it's often lovely to look at.
The two leads are playing roles they aren't suited for, and what's worse is that the only chemistry between them is what happens when an acid and a base meet.
As great as the effects are, Favreau remembers that they need to be serving something else.
Here's a spelling word for you: fatuous.

Jarhead might be Sam Mendes' first honest film.
Walk the Line isn't a bad film, but rather a frustratingly standard one.
I walked out with songs on my lips and a stitch in my side from laughing so hard.
To say that Munich is the most important film released this year is putting it mildly. To say that it's the best is being generous.

There's an interesting, if derivative (unless they never had The Matrix and Blade in Russia), imagination at work here.
Old fashioned storytelling that's moving and exciting.
Carrie Meets River's Edge.
A gorgeous and often moving film that perfectly captures the essence of Neil Young's acoustic work.
Yet another sad milestone in the valley of Steve Martin's career.

Tristram Shandy is going to be a cult classic.

movie_review_blurb: Looking For Comedy ends up being light fare for smarter people.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [Bubble takes] a concept that could have been the art house version of a sideshow and turns it into something exciting and real.
Annapolis is the perfect movie for someone who has never before seen one.
A blackly comic indictment of most aspects of our modern American middle class lives.
Ballsy, brash and utterly committed to the revolutionary power of cinema, Inglourious Basterds is a completely remarkable film.
Better than the original comic. Seriously.
While the film is well worth seeing, you might consider skipping it in theaters and renting the DVD on a night when it's dark, quiet and a little scary in your own house.
Sometimes I think Martin Scorsese's biggest flaw is that he makes creating masterpieces look so damn easy.
I liked Anchorman 2. And maybe in a couple of viewings I can shake off the disappointment that, while pretty good, this is not even close to being as good as the first film.

American Hustle is a relative of Goodfellas and Boogie Nights, although never quite as transcendently magical as those two films. Which just means it isn't one of the greatest movies ever made, so don't hold that against it.
I wish these beautiful scenes and images were in the service of a story that I enjoyed watching be told.
Congratulations, Millenials - you have your own disappointing Prequel Trilogy.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Halloween II is trying to be something more than 'just' a slasher movie, and while I don't think it's ever in any danger of succeeding I respect the fact that the guy tried.
A lot like the sperm that sets its plot in motion: it's mostly white, moves with a viscous sluggishness and is made up largely of glucose. You also would rather not get it in your eyes.

Walter Mitty isn't so much trying to tell a story or make us think about anything, it's trying to give us the feeling of diaphanous well-being we get from credit card commercials that feature smiling people in exotic locations.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It straddles the classic and the current in a way that will delight Disney geeks of all stripes, and its wonderfully girl-powered story melted the heart of even a Disney cynic like me.
CATCHING FIRE bests THE HUNGER GAMES in every way. If the trend continues this series will be a political science fiction epic that will endure for generations.

Thor: The Dark World is a movie that understands why we like these characters, how they work and how to best bounce them off each other. I'll forgive the overclocked pacing because the movie swept me so perfectly into a big, weird world.
Escape Plan is entertaining enough to keep it from being 'bad,' but there's so little different or interesting or truly engaging that it's not very good either.
The sort of unique, uncompromising movie that immediately undercuts the 'They don't make em like they used to' complaints.
Steve McQueen's latest masterpiece is a shattering horror film.
Zero Charisma is the nerd movie I've been hoping to see for years.
An unyielding exercise in extreme pain.

Berg shoots their every wound - and they suffer dozens, because while it takes one or two bullets to kill an Afghani it takes ten just to slow an American down - with a loving attention that calls to mind Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ.

No other film I have seen this year has the sort of visceral gut-wrenching terror and deep, complex humanity that Greengrass brings to Captain Phillips. In a career littered with highlights, this is one of his best.
I wanted to love The Monuments Men, and I spent the running time hoping it was a slow starter, that it would finally come together into something sublime. It never did.
A neutered movie that is constantly battling itself, ROBOCOP 2014 eventually reveals itself to be a hunk of junk, as inert as a robot cop when his plug is pulled.
Sitting through Transformers: Age of Extinction is like binge-watching the death of the human spirit.
Clint Eastwood suffocates the popular Broadway jukebox musical in this stiff, lifeless adaptation.

By doubling down on the chemistry between Tatum and Hill (and by giving Ice Cube a lot of room to be amazing), 22 Jump Street gets deeper and funnier than the first movie. It is, simply put, absolutely awesome.
Edge of Tomorrow is everything you wish summer blockbusters were - strong, charismatic central performances anchoring excellent FX work in the service of a well-constructed and smart story
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If Seth MacFarlane had made BLAZING SADDLES it would have been two hours of Gene Wilder exclaiming "Holy s**t, the West is RACIST!"
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Disney thought it would be a good idea to spend well over a hundred million dollars making a movie that shows the backstory of Sleeping Beauty to be a rape/revenge tale. It was, predictably, not a good idea.
It's what this series should have always been, a story about a small family of misfits who argue and disagree and sometimes betray each other, but who still can't help loving one another.
It's truly sleazy, and it's ridiculous. It's the kind of bad movie that a certain type of discerning connoisseur longs to discover.

So casually wrong-headed in its storytelling that it personifies the thorny concept of white privilege -o one involved in the movie considered whether this was actually the white guy's story they were telling.
It's worse than BATMAN FOREVER but slightly better than BATMAN & ROBIN.
Draft Day is a film that knows how to tell a good, traditional story and tell it well.

Outrageously ambitious and courageously complicated.
All you have to do is buy the soundtrack and skip the movie and you can create your own great version of Muppets Most Wanted in your living room, just like gulag prisoners putting on a show.
What makes Teenage truly special is the way it tells its story through the voices of the young.
NON-STOP is an extraordinary piece of cheese, a movie that elicits laughs (with the film), gasps and even some spontaneous applause.
They spent millions upon millions of dollars to make highly sophisticated computers recreate the look and feel of classic Toho monster brawl action, and it is absolutely glorious.
90 minutes of sheer excitement and terror, a dizzyingly participatory experience.
A very good film, with two hours of extraordinary, gripping filmmaking and twenty final minutes of subtle deflation.
The most magical movie ever is still magic in 3D IMAX.
If AIRPLANE! was Mad Magazine at its absolute best, a real genius work of insanity, SCARY MOVIE V is an issue you don't bother trying to get back after the teacher confiscates it.
If you were to order "42" at the ballpark you'd get a corndog.
Have you always wanted to watch Jurassic Park through Ian Malcolm's sunglasses? Then boy, is Jurassic Park 3D for you.

Not only a unique psychological spin on the entire story, but more importantly a truly heartbreaking examination of a 40 year old man who has spent his life trying to protect a wounded 10 year old boy within him.
Incredibly disjointed, lacks any sort of a compelling throughline and, in the end, feels very small. And that's with the entire city of London being destroyed from outer space.
Is Spring Breakers a party movie? Yes, but that party is a raging kegger, and it's happening amidst the ashes of Western civilization.
Funny enough fluff, the sort of movie that plays well on cable when you're just kind of lazing on the couch.
Like Tron Legacy, Oblivion is a beautiful, tedious, stupid movie that is an actual chore to endure.

It isn't that Evil Dead is particularly bad; it's fine. But it's without much of an identity; it's never allowed to become its own movie and is constantly forced to reference or bow to or swerve from the original.
This is what it looks like when no one cares about a movie. This is a movie as pure product, cinema rendered utterly soulless, with no aspirations beyond getting your money opening weekend.
There's nothing unifying A Good Day To Die Hard on a cinematic level besides the fact that every single scene, taken individually, sucks.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: S-VHS is a next generation improvement on the first film.
The Last Stand's action scenes range from shoot outs to crazy car stunts to a daring escape in Las Vegas to a great fist fight, and every sequence is fun and engaging.

A pulpy movie made by people who only know pulp from reading about it in movie reviews. It's the grim n' gritty version of DICK TRACY. And if you approach it like that, you'll enjoy the movie just fine.
Walking out of John Dies At The End I was seized with an enormous certainty that the film I just watched will become an enormous, long-lived cult film.
A giant turd of a movie that was made because someone had the rights to a brand name and needed to exercise them in a timely manner. The 3D sucks too.
A movie that feels elegantly transgressive and viscerally exciting. A wonderful, menacing and sexy thriller.
Instead of incoherent robot movies he doesn't even like, Michael Bay should have been making pitch black movies with the conscience of a sociopath all this time.
This isn't just the best Iron Man movie, it's a recharge to the whole shared universe concept. Marvel can make movies that exist together while still having unique, awesome identities of their own.
Logic and drama are what get purged here.
An extraordinary true story makes for a smart, adult, thrilling movie.
Riddick works. As a mid-range scifi action movie it's fun enough, if it never quite reaches the potential of that first act.

Yes, The World's End is funny and fun, and yes it will make you want to go get blasted at a traditional pub. But, like all the best science fiction, it also has a lot to say about humanity and who we are and how we screw up.
You're Next always keeps itself fun, always keeps itself moving and always gives the audience something to care about. What a weird gimmick: they made a movie that's actually just really good.
It's a loving, fun, extraordinarily well made celebration of the imagination and worldview of being 12. It's sweet but never sentimental. I loved it.
Jobs ends up being a fairly honest, only mildly bombastic look at the life of a man who was very, very complicated - which is code for 'a complete a-hole.'
Kick-Ass 2 is passable, but is completely missing the spark that made the original work.
It only took them six movies, but they finally got Wolverine right.
A hypnotic, terrifying plunge into neon hell.
A movie about that is thrillingly, upliftingly about the best of humanity. And it also has giant mechs punching the s**t out of giant monsters. This is what blockbuster movies should be.
I hate THE LONE RANGER as much as THE LONE RANGER hates The Lone Ranger.
White House Down is the new standard-bearer for what summer action fluff should be.
The funniest movie of the year.
The best superhero action ever put to film
