Justin Lin gives fans of this franchise what they want: greatcharacters being themselves and bouncing around in crazy, over the top action sequences.
A totally stupid movie, STAR TREK INTO DARKNESS falls apart as it goes, raining debris as it implodes like a building being demolished.
An incendiary agitprop scifi masterpiece.
A tedious, unpleasant experience that meanders on its way to a trite, pat conclusion.
Willow Creek isn't a joke. It's not a satire. It's an actual found footage horror movie that centers on Bigfoot... and it's actually scary.
Dawn is an incredible epic of conflict and humanity, a movie that - in the truest Planet of the Apes tradition - tells a story about our society using the figures of apes on horseback.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: CREED goes the distance, and is the best ROCKY movie since the original.
This is how the Hunger Games ends, not with a bang but with a whimper.
Entertainment is like having your nose rubbed in profound human despair almost two hours. And I liked it.
A genre-smashing confluence of an oater and an eater, Bone Tomahawk is an absolute blast even as it changes tones and takes on a profound gory grimness in the end.
A gothic romance, Crimson Peak is all about decaying mansions and withered aristocracy, sweeping heroic love and bitter villainous betrayal... and mutilated ghosts seeking justice.
I tend to cry at inspirational or hopeful or triumphant moments in movies. I must have cried a hundred times during The Martian.
THE VISIT is fun, first and foremost, with a lot of scares and laughs along the way to a climax that gets just nasty enough to qualify it as a real horror movie.
The Revenant is just the latest gorgeous, hollow and largely pointless work from a director who has convinced so many that his stark nudity is actually a sumptuous set of clothes.
Not since Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer has a movie gotten inside the head of a killer with such cold-blooded artistry.
Just like when a bar band plays a sweaty, messy cover of a great song, the movie's incredible and almost endless flaws can't get in the way of the true emotion at the core.
A cracking good science fiction movie... until the third act when it is dragged kicking and screaming into being a superhero movie and falls apart.
Barry Crimmins has the kind of story that could have been a footnote, but Goldthwait is determined to give this strong, funny, unique man his own spotlight again. I'm glad he did.
The best film in this series, and a perfectly realized piece of cinematic craftsmanship.
Magic Mike XXL is a joy, an affirmation of happiness, a movie that makes you feel better about yourself at every turn. It's a triumph.
Terminator Genisys might be the nadir of franchise filmmaking, a soulless exercise in keeping an IP going (and maintaining rights) at any cost.
A shattering documentary about a silenced voice.
A fierce and awesome movie that morphs into a standard biopic.
Inside Out is a movie that will make you a better human being.
A remix of the original STAR WARS that is saved by wonderful new iconic characters.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Witch is a slow, creepy burn that pays off spectacularly in crazy Satanic awesomeness that's just understated enough to be elegantly chilling.
Colossal operates largely as a deconstruction of a certain kind of romcom trope, but it's also a pretty legit kaiju movie.
A slow burn that ends on a great twisted horror note, Dearest Sister is a fantastic drama and character piece that is also inextricably a phenomenal and creepy ghost story.
SUICIDE SQUAD is a mess, but pushing against the current of a botched movie are four lead performances that salvage the whole thing.
SAUSAGE PARTY is what would happen if everyone at Pixar had syphilis.
This reboot has many of the qualities of the classic original: a great cast, a true affection for the supernatural, and a varied comedic tone. Hilarious!
Surprisingly beautiful sharp-toothed summer schlock.
A full-throated defense of a man whose work towers over so many of his peers and yet is so often casually dismissed
The Hateful Eight can be tough, but it's always rewarding as entertainment.

One of the most strikingly weird movies I have seen this year. The movie's examination of the life of the ultra-Orthodox Jews is fascinating and Sivan's actors - who simply can't really be Orthodox, can they? - are utterly convincing in all moments.
X-Men: Apocalypse the assembled a cast of excellent thespians who bring the burning hot energy of embarrassment felt by a kid whose mom walked in on him masturbating.
It needs to be seen on the big screen, and the biggest and the best screen possible. This movie is why we have movie theaters.
Civil War isn't great despite being the third Captain America and thirteenth overall Marvel movie - it's great because of those things.
In a world full of toxic masculinity, of #notallmen a-holes and GamerGate creeps, Everybody Wants Some!! is a welcome reminder that being a man isn't inherently bad.
To say that Superman v Batman: Dawn of Justice is a bad movie doesn't go far enough. This film feels like Zack Snyder hobbling the entire upcoming DC Movieverse before it gets started.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This charming, pop culture soaked movie admirably takes on racial issues but sags under the weight of its muddled metaphors.
Sure, it's about as shocking as a middle schooler giving his teacher the finger, but there's something adorable about that kind of juvenile nonsense.
For a movie that isn't 'good,' Warcraft simply works, and as the credits came up I found myself juggling my criticisms of the film with the desire to see just what happens next on Azeroth.
We don't experience awe, the film says, because we're jaded and distracted, but then the film fails to give us a single awe-filled moment.
Oh my God does Cameron Crowe try. Which is why it hurts so very much when he fails so very hard. And he fails catastrophically with Aloha.
The movie values neither human life nor audience entertainment, which is simply a lose/lose situation.
Two great performances and one big fake nose anchor this chilly tale of murder.
There's not much blood in the veins of A Most Violent Year - and even less on screen. This is one deeply mistitled movie.
The Hunger Games films are strikingly brilliant critiques of the military-entertainment complex.
Hiro and Baymax are characters in the best tradition of Elliott and ET and Hogarth and the Iron Giant.
If it weren't for the sex and violence I would have sworn Horns was made for 13 year olds.

It's a movie designed for people who watched the bedroom sequence in 2001: A Space Odyssey and wished there was more exposition about who built the room, how, why and what thread count was on that bed.
The single take gimmick is the heart of what's wrong with Birdman - it's cool, it's catchy, it's well done, it's screamingly obvious and eventually pointless.
Not a slow burn so much as a strong build up, and once STARRY EYES gets where it's going the film becomes explosively violent and shocking.
The most shocking thing about cheap-looking ANNABELLE, the haunted doll prequel to THE CONJURING, is that a major Hollywood studio is releasing it.
Merges LORD OF THE FLIES and THE HUNGER GAMES in a way that feels fresh, fun and surprisingly dangerous.
It took two movies, but The Expendables films finally learned their lesson - be dumb but be FUN.
Gleeful schlock that almost achieves bad movie greatness.
A MadLibs style superhero blockbuster, with each interchangeable beat and set piece placed into a skeletal structure that could support any characters in any story.
You'll laugh because the jokes are good, you'll clap because the action is awesome, but you'll get emotional because you truly care about the characters.
It's the stupidest possible movie about being smart, a sort of 2001 for people whose movie-going mantra is 'turn off your brain.'
Jeff ends up a movie that's not really about anything.
They don't make movies like A Walk Among The Tombstones anymore... and maybe that's a good thing.

Manages to evoke both outrage and sympathy - outrage at the incredibly unprofessional LAPD and sympathy with the people who live so far below the lines the authorities and media didn't even bother letting anybody know they're being picked off, one by one.
Besides being an offensive disservice to the sadly not singular tragedy of Alan Turing, how is The Imitation Game? Well, it has good performances.
It is certain that Felt is a beautiful film from one of the most exciting new directors working today, anchored by an astonishing performance by an artist without any previous acting experience.
Two hours of shaggy, pointless and often boring film hung on what should have been an editorial about the state of scifi.
A triumph. Every minute of MAD MAX: FURY ROAD had me smiling, and every action sequence had my heart pumping. It's a modern action movie masterpiece.
It doesn't have the fist-pumping highs of the first film, but AGE OF ULTRON is deeper, more emotional and all-around better.

The movie that is staggered by real life tragedy but refuses to be felled; it blurs the line between the world of the characters and the real world in a way that is so effective and affecting that the finale packs a humongous emotional punch.
It's not an interesting failure, it's not over-ambitious - CHAPPIE is just a bad movie.
FOCUS is pleasant and fizzy, but slightly too soft.
By drilling down into these two men and their conflict, Best of Enemies ends up having a lot to say about how we talk about politics and how we relate to -- and hate -- each other.
The Nightmare is guaranteed to produce plenty of real nightmares for audiences caught in its blood-red gaze.
The film's intense commitment to being dull makes you long for sparkly vampires and werewolves.
I'll say this for Seventh Son: it wanted to be over as badly as I wanted it to end.
Imaginative designs, but otherwise a rote CGI blockbuster that takes no chances narratively, cinematically or philosophically.
Punishingly bad.

If you can make it through the first fifteen minutes you'll be rewarded with a movie that's very funny, emotionally deep and has more, perhaps, to say about American interventionism than it does about the real Kim Jong Un.
It's a movie that uses dread and suspense, not cheap jump scares. It's also a movie that unsettles with deep psychological unpleasantness. And it's got a pretty killer title, as well.

I walked out of SELMA believing in this country, even amidst all the horror and tragedy we've been experiencing, because SELMA helped me remember that sometimes we're at our best in the face of injustice like this.
Legendary filmmaker Clint Eastwood has achieved another stunning cinematic milestone: he has made not one but two of the absolute worst movies of the year.
This is big screen filmmaking at its most traditional, a pageant of sight and sound that makes the trip to the theater completely worth it. Pity about the movie, though.

It doesn't so much begin as explode into existence, that ringing first chord shattering the quiet of the theater as the Beatles run towards the camera. TIt rarely backs down from this exuberant energy, barreling ahead with a constant cartoonish smile.

This is a movie created completely on its own terms, forged by the belief that audiences can pay attention, that audiences don't need everything spoonfed, that truth is just as exciting as fiction when presented well.
Let's put it this way: five years from now when you're talking about Oldboy, nobody's going to say 'Which one?'
It's not as bad as you feared, but not as good as you hoped.
Tron: Legacy could get away with a script as stupid as the one it has if the movie crackled, if any of the actors popped or if any of the action scenes felt truly next level or groundbreaking.
The Coens don't need to reinvent or deconstruct the Western. This isn't a 21st century take on anything, it's just a damn good Western story told damn well.
Frustrating as a standalone movie, DEATHLY HALLOWS nicely breaks the POTTER mold and gets us ready for the finale. But it feels like there should be an intermission, not a seven month wait.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, this is a genuinely so-bad-it's-good movie. This film is crushingly awful, tedious and moronic, but I was often howling with laughter.

This is a heavy handed thriller that has one goal - to keep you frozen in cheap suspense with that kernel of popcorn poised just outside your gaping mouth. It does that excellently, but does little else.
A non-stop buzz machine that runs on boobs and blood, offering everything you'd ever want to see in a movie whose logline is 'Thousands of prehistoric piranha attack Spring Breakers.
Elegiac, powerful, sweeping and personal, Animal Kingdom is one of the best films this year.
The Fighter is a crowd pleaser and an Oscar baiter. Bale gives one of the great performances of the year, and it's probably the best of his entire career.
There are movies opening this weekend that nobody will care about in a year; people will be packing theaters for revival screenings of Scott Pilgrim in 20 years.
I hope that you take a chance on this film.
Casey Affleck is suprisingly good as Ford.
As a first exposure to the history of The Doors I'd still recommend Oliver Stone's movie over this.
Get Low is a movie to savor for the exceptional performances.
The second half of Catfish is what raises the movie into something more than a snarky doc.
Inception is a masterpiece. Making a huge film with big ambitions, Christopher Nolan never missteps and manages to create a movie that, at times, feels like a miracle.

80 some odd minutes of bland, boring, tedious nonsense. Utterly inept and squandering potential at every opportunity, the only 'interesting' thing the film has going for it is an ending that is totally bizarro, terribly conceived and bafflingly stupid.
Surprise, it works.
I'm having a hard time remembering what the really funny bits in Get Him to the Greek were, exactly. I mean, I know I laughed. I just don't really remember why.
I'm in awe of this film... It's an all-encompassing, screen devouring vision of madness and art.
Mediocrity hangs thick around The Dilemma, like a fog hugging a beach.
This is what a summer movie should be - knowingly silly, fun, light, thrilling, packed with real stunts and not-so-subtle gayness.
If you ask someone 'What's your favorite scary movie?' and they answer Scream 4, they are a ****ing ***hole.
HANNA is the sort of movie that gives you faith in action films as not just ass-kicking or fun rides but as actual cinema
Mixing POLTERGEIST with Disney's Haunted Mansion ride, a staggeringly disappointing and silly second half mars INSIDIOUS' strong, scary first half.

The action in the film is thrilling and next level, the design of the world is incredible and gorgeous and the themes are deep, dark and haunting; an incredibly flawed piece of ambitious art that dazzles and excites.
There's nothing that gets you more juiced than a good story well told, with strong characters well acted, and that's what The Lincoln Lawyer offers up.
Paul's a road movie where the joy of hanging out with the characters is half the point, and these are characters that would be fun to revisit again and again.

Throughout THE GREEN HORNET I really wanted Jay Chou's Kato to beat the **** out of Seth Rogen's Britt Reid. That, in a nutshell, defines both the thing I liked most about GREEN HORNET and one of my biggest problems with the film.
Rango is the most beautiful animated film since the golden age of hand-drawn cartoons. Shame that the movie has no heart beneath all that beauty, though.
There's a lot of balls in Drive Angry, and even some brains, but no heart
Sometimes Unknown's tongue is so firmly in cheek that the audience doesn't even realize there's a joke happening.
THE EAGLE is a movie that should be better, that has a chance to be something unique and awesome, but ultimately stumbles.
SANCTUM is a soggy, shouty bit of fun.
The most amazing special effect in any Donnie Yen movie will always be Donnie Yen.
movie_title: Ip Man 2: Legend of the Grandmaster (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Rite doesn't just want to make you jump, it's looking to send you home unsettled. I don't think it succeeds, but the attempt is admirable.
In the tradition of Street Trash and the original Toxic Avenger, Hobo With A Shotgun is a gleefully over the top splatterfest with little redeeming social value.
The directors who once pushed boundaries with KINGPIN and THERE'S SOMETHING ABOUT MARY now defend them in HALL PASS.
As great as Hemsworth and Hiddleston are, they cannot overcome the film's flaws. All they can do is drag THOR up from awful to fairly tolerable.
I'm ready for another one, if they keep the bouncy, fun tone.
Filled with plenty of feather-light entertainment, Knight and Day is an enjoyable matinee that will dissolve away from you as step out into the summer sun, refreshed and smiling.
Ambitious, smart and unique, the film creates an entire world that is guaranteed to intrigue you and leave you wanting more.
While a movie that is deeply flawed and ultimately fails, Parnassus is at least watchable, unlike Gilliam's last film, the wretched Tideland.
At about nine minutes Police, Adjective might have been tolerable. At just shy of two hours it's a slog that would have Bela Tarr tearing out his hair.
It's not that I would call Sherlock Holmes 'smart,' as I don't think it ever truly is, but rather 'not stupid.'
It's not complicated: this movie sucks.
Cameron only cares that his characters are three dimensional visually. And he certainly doesn't care that his story is hackneyed, corny and trite.
The work of a master at his height. This is Scorsese flexing his muscles and cracking his knuckles and making a movie that's intense and thrilling and engrossing and beautiful and dense.
Denzel's Eli is one of those characters who, when he faces off against the hundred enemies, makes you feel bad for the hundred.
An amazing head trip, a glorious journey right inside a semi-innocent imagination
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's a certain irony in having a timeless tale about a man finding his soul being told in the most soulless way possible
2012 is well made spectacle. It's finely crafted trash. It's in on the joke, and it's laughing along with you.
For most of the running time of The Lovely Bones I thought the film was bad, but when the movie entered the final twenty minutes I realized my mistake: it's a disaster.
Tobey Maguire is the dark, compelling heart of Jim Sheridan's surprising new film.
Too smart to be a solidly mainstream film, too trite to be an art film, Up in the Air is perfectly, emptily middlebrow.
The most surprising thing about New Moon, the second film in the Twilight series, is how much worse it is than the first.
A masterpiece about the sorrows of growing up, about the pain of being a bright, creative, lonely, troubled child, about the search for love, acceptance, stability and comfort.
Ninja Assassin features gigabytes of blood being shed on screen.
With twenty or thirty minutes cut out The Karate Kid could be a grade A piece of entertainment; at this lumbering length it's too logey to truly compete in the tournament.
All hail the small movie.
What makes Frozen really work is the way that the characters react to their predicament.
When graded on the Pixar curve Toy Story 3 feels, even for all its scariness and darkness, kind of weightless.
Eclipse basically treads a whole bunch of the same ground we went over in the last terrible movie, except this time Jacob keeps coming across like a rapist in training.
Vincenzo Natali may be insane. In the best possible way.
Everything about this seems so unique, so weird, so interesting... so how did it end up just another rise and fall of a drug dealer story, just with a Yiddish accent?
MacGruber is an incredibly funny movie - a raunchy, silly, bloody ode to 80s action stylings. And to Will Forte's butt, which gets plenty of screentime.

The epitome of what's wrong with Hollywood's modern prequel mania - it tells no story, offers no new insight into the characters and is all about putting everybody into the positions you'd rather have seen them at in the beginning.
Superman has Kryptonite. Green Lantern is powerless against the color yellow. And if Iron Man 2 is any indication, Tony Stark's big weakness could be scripts.
This film could have been two hours of Gibson scanning through microfiche and it wouldn't have been any more dull.
I want to return to this hyper-violent, awesome world and get lost in laughs and sympathetic pain again.
A bore and an affront to anyone who is even familiar with the concept of Lewis Carroll and his books.
A film that takes the horrors visited upon millions as an excuse to tell the sad tale of a family who lost all their luggage.
A huge, sprawling meal of a film that feels like a new classic.
[An] utterly incompetent, painfully unfunny, ploddingly dull waste of time, money and life
While it never seems to really thematically gel and while I would have liked a better script, the actors and vision on display make this a better entry in the teeniest superhero subgenre yet.
Smart and thrilling and funny and wonderfully told.
Scary and fun and thrilling, The Wolfman brings the Universal Monsters back to the screen in a way that's fitting and modern and still respectful.
Feels like a movie that pays off on revisits, and like the kind of film that holds laughs that only get unlocked on a third viewing.
Is this the female version of The Hangover? No - Bridesmaids is much funnier and way more heartfelt and human than that film.
Jettisons any psychological aspects that Romero explored in favor of cheap, stupid jump scares accompanied by cacophonous shrieks on the soundtrack.
An awesome work of filmmaking, an incredibly masterful and haunting and beautiful piece. This is big art, and it is worth more than one viewing.

There's lots of talent on display in the film (and I think the film will make a good display movie for your home theater one day), but none of it matters when the script is so saggy and the lead so wrong.
The struggles these guys face getting their games done are monumental, and makes for some really tense, anxious stuff.
Director Peter Berg engages in Michael Bay fetishism the way one might say Ed Gein engaged in female festishism.
The Dictator feels almost exactly like a Saturday Night Live movie from the 90s.
The Avengers proves these guys truly are Earth's Mightiest Heroes.
You may find yourself a dedicated follower of Maggie in the end. I know I am.
If you're a Stooges fan, go see the movie. If you like crude, silly slapstick, go see the movie. If you have a stick up your ass, go see Titanic.
Moonrise Kingdom feels like a culmination, like Anderson has been working towards this one movie.
I would accuse American Reunion of being misogynistic, but the movie seems to hold all of humanity in contempt, not just women.
It would have been impressive if the 21 Jump Street movie was any good. The fact that it's flat-out great feels like showboating by directors Phil Lord and Chris Miller.
You'll feel like horror is revitalized, like its importance is more obvious than ever. That might be Cabin's greatest achievement, reminding us why we love and need this genre.
Hilarious.

Often spectacular, with stunning action and thrilling moments, it's a film that captures the pulpy, swashbuckling sensibilities of Burroughs while updating much of the whiz bang for an audience a century older than the original novels.
This is a movie of shattering ineptitude, starting at the script and reaching into every aspect of the cheap, rushed, sh***y-looking production.
Safe House will have you on the edge of your seat - so you can spring out of it the second the credits roll.

A strong, well-told science fiction movie that uses its fantastical ideas to explore grounded human emotions. It's got vivid action and it has cool concepts, but most of it all it has great characters.
The Hunger Games is largely a triumph of smart, brave, timely, heady science fiction that recalls the 60s and 70s era of big idea scifi.
Fascinating and beautiful and brutal
In space no one can hear PROMETHEUS disappoint you.
The only thing amazing about this movie is how badly it goes off the rails.
Pirates 4 is the epitome of lazy filmmaking, a movie without a single clever moment, without the least bit of inspiration. It's a paint by numbers film, charmless and witless.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful, moving, infuriating experience. Everyone should see this movie.
It's not a movie that feels designed to sell toys, it's a movie that feels designed to spark imaginations.
Bill Condon cannot, for all his skill and effort, overcome the essentially s**t nature of the source material.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Spielberg has made a movie about thinkers and debaters for thinkers and debaters. He has made a movie where eloquence and conviction are the action elements, not chases and explosions.
Silver Linings Playbook is the sort of feel-good claptrap that normally irritates me, but Russell plays it with the pitch and verve of a classic screwball comedy.
Yeah, I said it. Wreck-It Ralph compares with the Toy Story movies. It's the equal to those films in terms of joy, character, sweetness and, most of all, heart.
BRAVE would be a pretty good Dreamworks movie, but with the Pixar history we hope for so much more.
FLIGHT stumbles along for a punishing two hours and twenty minutes, barely ever making any nods in the general direction of drama beyond the intense opening plane crash.
[Villain] Mr. Boogie shows up too often to be effective, but is kept too mysterious to be interesting. Also, he looks like a heavy metal band's attempt to create their own Eddie-like mascot.
Paul Thomas Anderson is obviously at the height of his powers right now, and he has crafted a character piece that is enthralling and engulfing.
CLOUD ATLAS left me with an incredible sense of hope for the future of cinema. And the future of humanity. How many movies give you that?
THE POSSESSION gave me the willies. It's a well-made, smart horror movie.
In some ways it's an action star minstrel show; they're all doing their famous lines and shuffling across the screen hoping for some tiny bit of love from the audience.
The film, while echoing The Bourne Identity, is adequate enough (not the highest praise, I know) and creates enough space for itself to warrant further adventures.

The whole movie feels so like a series of contradictions - bloated and long yet rushed, deeply serious yet utterly silly, politically minded yet ultimately vapid - that being both wildly entertaining and a bad movie would be exactly right for it.
Every time a Bond fan extols the virtues of the Bond films I wish I could see what they saw. I finally have, and I saw it in SKYFALL.
If we had one like this a month - lean, smart, muscular, thematically coherent and filled with good character actors - the cinema would be in remarkably good shape.
A totally forgettable piece of substandard sitcom fluff that will one day be a blip on Ari Graynor's resume.
There are sequences of such breathtaking skill and confidence that I believe the film must be seen by everyone who ever hopes to make, or even talk intelligently, about movies.

The technology and performances that bring the apes to life make the film a must-see for any modern movie fan, but it's the emotion and humanity of Caesar's story that makes the film a must-see for any movie fan at all.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A perfect genre gem, a movie that works a crowd the way a great song works a crowd. Paced beautifully, written smartly and shot with style and energy.
This movie is the definition of a dud, something that just sits inert on screen.
A rollicking old-fashioned adventure story - two fisted, over the top and filled with retro scifi flair.
The ultimate poseur movie... [A cinematic] temporary tattoo, a way of feeling underground without ever committing to anything real.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: That Another Earth disappoints is crushing.
The film alternates between being heavy handed and moronic, and it seems to be informed by a 15 year olds' understanding of Waco filtered through the paranoid ramblings of a stoner.
Badly written, lethargically directed, smothering the few fun performances that could have saved it, Fright Night 3D sucks.
It's completely satisfying on the level of an FX-driven summer blockbuster. But most importantly it's satisfying on the level of a great drama.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Transformers 3 is the Michele Bachmann of cinema. Despite all of its staggering flaws it will have its supporters, and its success is part of a trend of accepting less and pretending it's more.
It feels like Bad Teacher is crossing a line, and not just by a toe but hurdling all the way across. Good for everybody involved.
There was a lot of potential in Green Lantern, almost all of it squandered.
Ironclad is the sort of movie where they behand three people in a row.
I was caught by surprise at the twist ending, but that was mostly because I didn't think any movie - even one as abysmally written as this one - would be dumb enough to go there.
While it has good performances and looks pretty, SUPER 8 is a movie that, in the end, does not fully work on any level except for cheap nostalgia porn.

The best praise I can give X-Men: First Class is that it's a wonderful movie, not just a wonderful X-Men movie or a wonderful Marvel movie or a wonderful superhero movie. It's a damn good film, full stop, all other genres and ghetto-izations aside.
It could almost be argued that Horrible Bosses' general middle of the road, vanilla, just-good-enough nature is actually on purpose, a reflection of the lead characters' own qualities.
In space no one can hear you yawn.
Muddled, overlong, indulgent in uninteresting ways and eventually afraid to go any place provocative, Bellflower has only a cool car and a promise of future filmmaking from talented first timers.
ROCKY with rivets.
Wickedly funny, the kind of semi-dark comedy that really gets right up to the line of mean-spiritedness.
Watching the legendarily cool Jack Nicholson literally CRYING about Roger Corman will put a lump in the throat of even the most jaded viewer.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A legitimately great action film, a thrilling and fun bit of exquisitely crafted escapism. It might be the best in the series, and it's without a doubt the best since the first film.
The Hangover Part II never makes a convincing argument for its existence, but it works exactly as much as it has to in order to not be a bad movie.

the touches that made the first film a surprise seem to have disappeared. The Holmes/Watson relationship is now shrill, the facade of a mystery story has been chucked for a nation-hopping action adventure, and the volume has been turned up to 12.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The scariest cinematic image of the year is a lingering shot of a grimy pole on a public bus.
We Bought A Zoo is targeted at people who cry during TV commercials, who get misty eyed in the greeting card aisle.

A deeply felt, hugely personal, glorious and heart-swelling ode to the magic of cinema and stories: the way they bring us together, allow us to understand each other, allow us to see our dreams come true.
I don't know why The Muppets faded away over the last couple of decades, but [this film] proves that they still have plenty of heart and smart-assness to give to a new generation and beyond.
If The Artist truly were from the period it's about, it would be a minor film that occasionally played on TCM at 3AM, and about which even hardcore silent film fans wouldn't care much.
PARANORMAL ACTIVITY 3 feels the most like a real film, even though it sticks to the exhausted found footage format of the first two.
To me there's no better praise you can give to a crime film -- when a hood gets his comeuppance you don't feel thrilled but bummed out.
Every dance sequence in the film is simply spectacular.
Depraved and disgusting but intellectually active, The Human Centipede 2 never fully coheres as a movie but works incredibly as a screed of cultural critique.
Smart and as exciting as a thriller, with killer performances. Ryan Gosling is magnificent.
Emotional without being cloying, honest and funny and low key.
Playing like the excruciatingly long first act of a better movie, Take Shelter long overstays its welcome while confusing narrative indolence for tension.
The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 1 might be the most beautiful and well made bad film in history.
... has many astonishing revelations to share about our country's drug and alcohol crisis.
... "Superbad" isn't perfect. But it's super close.

Snyder has appropriated Moore's doomsday themes without any sense of how to animate them. That's the trouble with loyalty. Too little, and you alienate your core fans. Too much, and you lose everyone -- and everything -- else.
The zombie-movie genre already has some wink-wink funny entries, but this U.K. smash hit, written by Pegg and Wright, takes the prize. It's a bloody hoot.

Arrietty combines the bold, mature qualities of prior Ghibli fantasy outings like Spirited Away and Nausicaa with the droll humor of My Neighbor Totoro, resulting in a movie that is simultaneously thrilling and whimsically adorable.
Considering how little he had to work with and how harried the production schedule was, that the film plays as well as it does is truly impressive, despite occasional hiccups.
We finally get our Lassiter moment, and boy is it a textbook definition of "poignant."
... an emotional kaleidoscope, and a masterpiece.
It's a neat little bit of hagiography, dwelling fondly on his quirks, but that's OK. For people who want to taste the world, Gold is a patron saint.
Rated reveals the mysterious ways of the movie ratings board, otherwise known as the MPAA, and you won't believe your eyes.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Even if you haven't been in this exact situation, if you ever did, this Judd Apatow fella would totally know what it's like.
An Ocean that fulfills the promise of all this great talent.
Will Pixar ever make a bad movie? Ever?
For what could have been a stupid gross-out comedy (and let's face it, in the end it still ain't Masterpiece Theatre) has the ever-so-slightest hint of wit and goodwill.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An appropriate palate cleanser in between noisy summer action flicks.
[Samberg] falls a lot in Hot Rod, but this stuntman farce simply isn't worth falling for.
The dialogue is stupid, the plot is stupid, and unfortunately, the stars are as brainless as their plastic counterparts. This is girl power?
It's all obtusely broad and ridiculous, and the dreaded 'life lessons' drag it out interminably.
It's inevitable that a movie this trigger-happy shoots itself in the foot.
What floats the movie are Sparrow's grandiose gestures, his schoolyard bickering with Barbossa and the charmingly funny crew of the Black Pearl that provides trusty backup at every challenge.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Thoughtful action picture? Meditation on grieving? The Brave One tries to be both but just misses its target, despite the presence of a magnetic Jodie Foster.
Elizabeth's appeal is that she was womanly and feminine while deftly executing matters of state in a time when men ruled most of the world.
It dilutes its message.
Bring your tissues, ladies. Halle Berry and Benicio Del Toro act their hearts out in a modern weepie that manages to hit all the marks, without being too terribly predictable.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It could have been so easy for this story, about a single man adopting a troubled kid, to enter schmaltzville. But John Cusack manages to deliver plenty of warm fuzzies -- without the sugar shock.
Amy Adams shines in this fabulous fable about what happens when the fairy tale world takes a bite out of the Big Apple.
It could be this year's Little Miss Sunshine, another funny, poignant and sincere take on family life served up with a raw indie sensibility.
It comes as a pleasant relief then to discover that the movie has its heart and soul in the right place.
You know that relative you dread seeing at holiday gatherings? Now imagine they look like Nicole Kidman and you're stuck in the same dark room with her for 90 minutes.
The dialogue is so one-note, the plot absurd, and most attempts at humor fall flat.
Breathless action sequences are balanced with a sensitive interpretation of the political and cultural gray areas of (Mid)East-West relations.
It's an honest hard look at a very messy family, with a fantastic cast. The movie threatens to lose its way -- and its audience -- but ends up right where it should by the last scene.
A sweet but supermellow tale that needs a shot of espresso on the side to keep things lively.
High-concept, totally ludicrous, laugh-out-loud nonsense that is best fit for late-night television when nothing else is on.
Improvisation is an art, and the actors here handle it well, which is impressive enough. But the movie presents few flashes of brilliance or memorable belly laughs.
... these are truly vulnerable, hopeful characters who actually deserve our cheers.

The movie creeps along at times with extraneous material, but it succeeds in doing something unique, by filtering a time of turmoil through the experience of one of the most fascinating artists of our time.
With clunky dialogue, jokes that fall flat and an uneven sense of rhythm and timing, the movie looks and feels too amateurish to take on this kind of material.
This may be one of those cases in which the soundtrack is better than the movie.

Instead of a highly relevant political satire, writer-director Barry Levinson takes the easy way out and churns a paint-by-numbers tale of corporate malfeasance. Guess he had no special interests in creating a smart, savvy comedy.
Cohen has updated the art of racial satire for a new, troubled world, and Borat is its king.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Harris officially bites off more scenery than he can chew.
For Your Consideration accurately hits La-La Land where it hurts, but at the expense of the rich characterization and sweet-natured comedy that made Guest's other flicks instant classics. Too bad.
A little surrealism to advance the theme of the movie is brave; a lot of tedious navel-gazing is just selfish.
The Nativity Story is no whitewashed Christmas pageant, but it's no masterpiece either.
Just another lame tween screwball comedy (emphasis on the 'screwball', not so much on the 'comedy').
Had we seen an intimate glimpse into the professional side of Gardner's journey, this likeable but unexceptional fable could have been so much more.
Better than almost any other filmmaker, Eastwood understands that the story's words and actions alone get the point across that war is hell, even for the enemy.
McG is conducting a one-note symphony, losing the impact of the real story of Marshall University.

Director Alfonso Cuarón takes his career to a whole other level here. He expertly preys on our doomsday fears, punctuating scenes with the harsh sounds and images of war we've already heard and seen on the nightly news.
Freedom Writers will follow you right out of the movie theatre and into your own head and heart.
Beloved kids' novel makes it to the big-screen unscathed, with very real childhood relationships, surreal special effects and a big weepie ending.
Not helping matters are the over-the-top moments so typical of director Joel Schumacher's oeuvre.
Schlocky, obvious fight-flick that gets the shock job done, but at the expense of subtly, fun and, possibly, Hilary Swank's career.
Tightly scripted, good old-fashioned crime drama pitting two of our finest actors against each other in the courtroom. Not one computer effect or clichéd one-liner to be found.
Sure, the jokes are obvious, the plot's a little corny -- but c'mon, it's a movie about talking chipmunks.
When you can tell the cast is having fun, it's kind of hard not to yourself.
It doesn't work all the time, but it's definitely a worthy attempt.
If there's a God, First Sunday will be the last of its kind for Ice Cube and Tracy Morgan, who deserve better than this wannabe screwball comedy about small-time crooks knocking over a church.
Funny, inspiring and gorgeously rendered, The Princess and the Frog is an instant classic.
Absorbing, often electric with the energy of the playing field, Invictus is packed with feel-good "teachable moments" without the sugary aftertaste.

The forced misunderstandings, clumsy attempts at comedy, and late-third-act turnarounds are so absolutely rote and graceless that not even the charm of the poor actors consigned to this eye-roller can lift the movie out of its grave.

The clashes between Roger and his old friends and bandmates shine a light on the fact that you either have to accept your lost dreams, or fight for them all over again, no matter how much your knees ache or your joints creak.
Despite several attempts at jokes and the stars' tremendous efforts to pull funny faces, the script fails miserably to entertain; most of the dialogue is tiresome bickering between our two leads.
It's no comedy masterpiece, but this story of a funeral where everything goes wrong has a brash, outlandish tone grounded by an outstanding cast.

It's almost like the movie is afraid of what it should be -- a young, frisky love story that should be exuberant and carefree, even if it means risking making a fool of itself. What's love, after all, if it doesn't do exactly that?
Sex and the City 2 has very little sex, and not a lot of city. Bad move.
A lame, worn-out story wrapped in a pelt of fluffy dog fur.

Like a kung-fu master poised on one leg, a movie must have balance -- between action and emotion, heart and head, fast and slow. This rebooted Kid wobbles, flails, and ultimately stumbles in a futile attempt to top the original.
Another sentimental journey with some old friends, new scene-stealers and a powerful, heartfelt mix of sugar and spice.
Relative unknown Joey King, as Ramona, is on the right side of precocious, using her adorableness in carefully measured doses. She easily carries the movie.
A well-crafted tearjerker with a grown-up performance from Zac Efron. If you don't mind risking dehydration, it's the movie for you.
Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg milk dry their default movie personas, but it's all part of the joke -- and what a great joke it is.
Most of what made the book connect with so many is entirely missing here.

The personalities are exuberant, the situations humorous, the slapstick worth a chuckle or two.
Those expecting a trademark Vince Vaughn Wedding Crashers-style laughfest will be disappointed-and those who hate Vince Vaughn Wedding Crashers-style laughfests will be surprisingly impressed.
eteran TV producer John Wells filters the economic disaster through the eyes of the laid-off, but not even Ben Affleck and Tommy Lee Jones can save this uneven movie.
A thoroughly delightful, fast-paced tale about a young lady finding adventure and love.
A beautifully shot, designed and plotted movie that has a little something for everyone -- top-notch acting, passionate romance, humor and suspense.
Starring bright animation and the voices of Justin Long and Dawyne Johnson, Planet 51 follows a hilarious concept with weak execution and way too many references to better films.

Practical jokes, general buffoonery and sexual misadventures abound, and a sentimental "who's your daddy" subplot involving Carl barely registers amidst the guffaws. War? Recession? Unemployment? Forget all that in this buoyant flick.
Precious is an exhausting but worthwhile ride, a movie that shines a light on the dark side of humanity and the opportunity to rise above it.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Bride Wars could have been a clever, incisive satire of the bloated and maddening wedding industry; unfortunately it takes an old-fashioned stance far out of place in this modern world.

Nothing, not even the voice of Darth Vadar himself, can save this family comedy from a too-silly script.

About as unpopular as the war in Iraq are movies about the war in Iraq, but no matter: Director Kimberly Peirce emerges victorious with a brave, probing look at the inner lives of soldiers.
This supposed adventure movie could use a little more wind in its sails.
Music can move you, no matter what style, no matter who performs. That's the most poignant lesson of Young@Heart.
Congrats, Jason Segel, the latest lucky graduate of the Judd Apatow School of Movie Stardom.
It's a perfectly bred combination of razor-sharp satire and female buddy comedy.
Full of quirk, slapstick and dry British humor, Son of Rambow is a delight, but too often forgets to stay true to its heart.

The tension between the leads is almost lost in the white noise of vindictive bridesmaids, fussy future in-laws and one too many dirty sex jokes, leading right up to the oh-so-predictable grand finale.

A gritty aesthetic and clearheaded storytelling elevate this conventional plot into an engrossing drama.

We understand -- immediately, like in the second or third scene, thank you -- that they are tragically suppressed; why should we care?
Mamma Mia! lacks even one big fantastic set piece; visually, each musical number is chopped up into tiny little bits.

This enjoyable timepiece is notable today for its peppy score, energetic dancing, and for having made a star of the extremely nubile Ann-Margret, 22 passing for 16. Her fresh, wholesome eroticism fairly bursts off the screen.

It's a movie that you can watch again and again, and hardcore Bollywood fans do. But even if you just watch Sholay once, you won't be disappointed.

This picture is something you don't see every day, no matter the gender -- the bright light of a genuine hero.
Hanging Up is so drippy it really should be hung out to dry.

A challenging and arresting story that unearths compelling insights.

The insights in this script rarely rise above the level of an acrostic puzzle.
Intriguing to watch.
Unfortunately, schmaltz seems to be the main ingredient in this particular kettle of fish.

Vibrant and darkly funny.
Witty!
If you like your sentiment layered on thick and creamy as a slab of mascarpone cheese, Return to Me is one to go back for.

Compelling and cogent ...

Sweetly odd ...
Like a mountaineer grappling on sheet ice, the film's focus on performance can result in a loss of footing.
As one journalist tells Weisman, "Information is the weapon." It's worthwhile to understand how it's being used.

movie_review_blurb: It's too rare for movies to depict women working together as friends to effect political change, and this one makes it seem righteous, loud, and fun as a rock concert.
A delicious, compact viewing experience - like a rich, smooth shot of espresso.
movie_title: A Small Section Of The World (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A deeply human reminder that there's plenty of beauty around us right now.
What a relief to watch this small, expert film - a pane of glass in a concrete wall - that whispers, that dares to stand still and witness ordinary human pain.

movie_title: Walking The Camino: Six Ways To Santiago (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its context in a global conflict, Uprising is a strangely intimate film.

movie_review_blurb: Friedrich, so impassioned by her subject matter, couldn't get enough objectivity to make a film that's more than just a complaint.

An enraging portrait of entrenched sexism in competitive sports that proves parity is worth fighting for.
movie_title: Half The Road: The Passion, Pitfalls & Power Of Women's Professional Cycling (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Weber's expertise, tenderness, and taste for the absurd become clear.

As intuitive as its structure, as natural as the processes of dying and mourning that make up its core.

movie_title: Evergreen: The Road to Legalization in Washington (2014)

For a film encompassing generations of fraught history, Germans & Jews is awfully short, but hardly superficial.

[A] tremendous documentary ...
Like a well-executed fine-dining experience, this sleek documentary entertains, delights, and makes viewers comfortable without evident sweat.

movie_review_blurb: Though sometimes clumsy or nostalgic, the film is an engaging oral history of Leary and Dass's friendship.
movie_title: Dying To Know: Ram Dass & Timothy Leary (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Vital, complicated and flawed ... necessary viewing.
It insists on seeing its subjects' humanity - something rare in the Western press, particularly when reporting on Islam, and especially fundamentalism.

The film is a space for listening, for trying to understand.
The images are augmented by commentary from Benson, his subjects, and his critics, who include his own family.
Although Speed Sisters is not comprehensive, it's vital.
Of course the film plods; this story is exhausting, drawn-out, decades of fear and violence so familiar that they hardly even shock.

Cutting between present, childhood, and recent past, Bispuri constructs a subtle, richly emotional collage.
It's hard to keep watching. Don't stop.
Surreal and wordlessly unsettling, Eduardo Williams' globe-crossing feature The Human Surge is intimate and pleasurably inscrutable.
movie_title: The Human Surge (El auge del humano) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's beautiful and important and very strange.
This strange, quiet film takes social narratives about romance and gender and upends them, often seeming like one thing until it's another.
This film does not pander. Rather, it demands that the viewer rise to the occasion.
It's rare to find a film that portrays dancers of all shapes, colors, ages, and sizes as beautiful, which they are.
A serious, fascinating, slightly lurid documentary for devoted Al Jazeera viewers and fans of the movie Her.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This gripping documentary about unleavened bread and the people who need it asks us to consider what we in the world owe one another - and demands that we do better.
movie_title: Streit's: Matzo And The American Dream (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A dance is not only motion, but emotion. This fascinating film reminds us how closely the two are linked.
[A] fascinating, unnerving documentary.
In My Father's House doesn't spend much time on politics, examining why rates of fatherlessness are so high among black American families, but it doesn't need to.
A mightily silly but occasionally insightful, and certainly entertaining, film.
[A] disturbing, vivid documentary ...

Disregard your personal feelings about the military, U.S. involvement in foreign wars, or a French director making a movie about Americans. This film is raw in the truest sense, yet refined in its sympathy and scope.
Despite a melodramatic title, the film is keen and measured. Drama builds in the small moments.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Oz is the best-known novelist in Israel, notorious for supporting a two-state solution. If you don't yet understand why he does, watch this film. If you're already on Oz's side, keeping the wound open might be worth it.
Some of what the interviewees say will be offensive, no matter your point of view. Go and listen. Bring a friend so you can keep the discussion going after the credits roll.
By glamorizing struggle and ideology across the Israeli-Jewish political spectrum, it once more invites identification with only half of those locked in the conflict Rabin was trying to solve.

How can everyone go home? It's an impossible question, but a vital one. By listening deeply, Dorman and Rudavsky suggest that, even if there might not be an answer, we can always change the story; see how it already has changed, so many times?
Dukhtar is an issues film with the twisted, heart-pounding feel of a road-trip thriller ...
Vack is sexy and charming, but Dyer carries the film, the camera holding her expressive face in close-up, wavering between pain and wonder.
La La Land may look like the world that we dream about, but it also understands the cruelty that can come out of (or undermine) those dreams.
The connections are apparent, but forced; the attempted cinematic blood transfusion does not flow smoothly, and the film winds up in agony, along with its audience.
movie_title: Blood Of My Blood (Sangue Del Mio Sangue) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This tragicomedy asks how many times a continent can die and not draw any new conclusions from the experience.
[Indivisible] offers redemption rather than punishment, and offering several powerful variations on the theme of freedom.
The director's attempts to provoke and disturb are straight out of a textbook. The film is not complex.
Despite the fulsomeness of Ford's cinematic reference points, one can't avoid the feeling that something crucial is still missing.
The Danish Girl is imperfect and sometimes cloying, but in its own way beautiful and honest. Its message is that everyone should have the right and courage to fight for their happiness.
This liquified Chanel ad doesn't take us to heaven along the way-it just plunges us into an infernal abyss of boredom.

While the idea of hope rising from the ashes of tragedy might work on paper, in practice it undermines the severity of what has come before. The shift in mood suggests a film that is finally, for all its sinister power, quite naïve.
Vigas makes the viewer wonder: How thin is this line? Where do the limits of indifference, repulsion, devotion, obsession, or maybe even true love end?
The main disappointment of Looking for Grace is the finale, which replaces the Altmanesque ensemble style with something reminiscent of Kiéslowski's last works.
Ignorance and conformity infect the family dynamic. Terror is everywhere. This is a film with a very modern vision.
The real revelation of the film is the seductive and stunningly beautiful lead actress, Manal Issa: her transformation is captivating, convincing, and seemingly effortless. She's a delight.
Marcin Wrona is attempting to make a serious movie within a genre framework, and he succeeds in balancing the right amounts of fear, humour, and grotesquerie.
It's not brilliant, it's rather predictable, but it's ok; it bowls along nicely and it does make you jump. What more can you ask of dinosaurs?

The sincerity and earnestness of Stand Clear of the Closing Doors are brave and true and I applaud not only the actors, but the screenwriters and director Sam Fleischner for putting so much on the line and in the open.
movie_title: Stand Clear Of The Closing Doors (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film not only tugs at the heartstrings but also immerses the audience into its subjects' storylines and culture.
13th speaks to a populace jaded by the status quo and encourages them to reexamine their own preconceptions and prejudices.
The computer effects, which I'm always a bit wary of in live action films, is much more Babe than Alvin and the Chipmunks.
The subtle build of anticipation makes the coming of age romance Call Me By Your Name so irresistibly delicious.

Thanks to its finely honed timing, hilarious one-liners, quirky characters and non-stop laughs, 'Death at a Funeral' is enormously funny.
An edge-of-your-seat thriller with incredible performances by Bale, Foster and Crowe.
Morning Glory is a great story with Hollywood glamour and exceptional performances.
My one complaint about this otherwise excellent film involves the ending, which doesn't ring true to me.
Jackson sheds all elements of ego and literally becomes a disheveled homeless man in appearance, with his wispy voice and his mindless emotional baggage.
Daniel Craig and Nicole Kidman have too much talent to be pigeon-holed in such limited roles.
Pixar/Disney's latest animated movie Ratatouille could be a trap, as it ensnares viewers from start to finish with its adorable animation, non-stop humor and lovable characters.
A delightful romp with an intriguing story that could have been cut by 30 minutes and not missed a beat.
The film probably won't win Oscars but it's an entertaining romantic story with top-notch actors and a bit of fun and creative maneuvering in the kitchen.
An enthralling story that explores the human spirit in the most devastating of circumstances.
Energetic, funny and entertaining; there's nothing stiff about Hairspray
A world shrouded by danger, suspicion, and family disloyalty comprised of commonplace characters brought to life by exceptional actors.
A forthright and compelling film but Angelina Jolie has become so notable, I could never forget she was playing a role.
The comical, surprising De Niro turns Stardust into meteors of laughter.
Although we've seen many films about high-profile law firms versus the average Joe, watching Michael Clayton becomes more compelling every minute.

movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Why aren't these actors helping troops' families or give injured solders jobs in movies so they can support their loved ones? No matter what side of this issue you support, standing on the sidelines and throwing stones only leads to more stone-throwing.

The first time you stare into Halle Berry's iris, it's interesting; by the fifth and sixth time it's exasperating.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a shame that Smith's heartfelt work and preparation doesn't pay off with better background and CGI work.
The pretzel-like personality of Brooks is expertly weaved and salted with just a hint of compassion to evoke an odd sort of understanding from the viewers.
A good date movie with more stars than script appeal.
Shrek the Third, lacks everything that made the first two Shreks so entertaining.
A safe mix of fantasy and fright, the adventurous tale The Spiderwick Chronicles fills a gap in solid entertainment for children and adults.

There's a storyline involving emperors, chastity belts, and metal plates, but it's slightly confusing and largely nonsensical.
This is one of those nasty little films that tries very hard to obscure its misogynist and racist premise through pseudo political critique.
Meanders through the world-making works of landscape artist Anselm Kiefer in reverential awe and little skepticism.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Chris Marker territory, but here the ideas are firmly anchored in specific characters who become more fleshly as the storytelling patchwork unfolds.
movie_title: La bocca del lupo (The Mouth of the Wolf) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Approaches the coming-of-age story of the Chicana girl unwilling to reproduce "her" culture without putting up a fight developing some unconventional threads.
The film ultimately promises controversial content too literally, and through tediously normative form.
I'd take raw shots of sweat dripping on pavement and heavy panting over slick graphics and guitar-strumming any day.
Here the yardstick for measuring existential accomplishment is to beat someone at something in the most spectacular way possible.
Hovering over the narrative is the fear of the domino effect that change can enact, the dread that one person's "queerness" may perhaps expose everyone else's.

It packs its narrative with a succession of increasingly clichéd twists, one of which involves the sudden recognition that its main character, Foley (Samuel L. Jackson), is romantically involved with his own daughter.

While We the Party can be insensitive, or blind, to the misogyny and homophobia of the general culture (the token gay teen is a finger-snapping, head-bobbing fashionista), it takes the issues of race and class quite seriously.
Without a consistent stylistic playfulness to match the histrionic scenarios, the action often feels just plain silly.
Its most redeeming quality is that it isn't so quick to neuter its queer characters into a package-friendly "gay couple" aesthetic a la Modern Family.
In Our Nature's visual style seems plastered on or allocated, not developed with any sort of authorial singularity.
The film decides very early on, as part of its premise, to reduce Louisa Krause's King Kelly to a one-dimensional narcissist.
It's Jonathan Caouette's insistence in going back to his nightmarish old footage, or the old footage that he purposefully renders nightmarish, that seems more interesting.
Susan Youssef isn't consistent in her approach to the impossibility of love.
The film works as a charming aesthetic exercise with its jerky camera and inadvertent cuts, as a contemplation on intergenerational female bonding.
The doc does a major disservice to an artiste of fashion with a pretty amazing and prolific oeuvre by reducing him to a Bravo-like personality.
Sassy Pants has a slightly ludic atmosphere akin to another tale of teen alienation, Dear Lemon Lima, but it unfolds like a fable in which only Bethany doesn't feel like a canned caricature.
The hilarity of the film creeps up slowly and from every angle, not through the facile immediacy of short-lived laughter.
Though there's something refreshing, and disturbingly familiar, about Kevin Sheppard's spontaneity, he's certainly not the most interesting thing about the film.
The film is at its best when it lingers on intimacy and the characters' incompetency to manage it.
There's no pointing toward something other than the work itself, no poetic digression, no suggestion of a conceptual dimensionality to the work being produced.
The film is often too cheesy to, well, bear.
The film captures Vreeland's perhaps unwitting philosophical integrity just as much as it drowns us in the exuberance of her work.
movie_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has To Travel (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Do we really need another film about underachieving white men with scruffy beards? Ryan O'Nan thinks so.
movie_title: The Brooklyn Brothers Beat The Best (2012)

movie_review_blurb: We empathize with their resistance to suffer, but it's hard to feel something other than philosophical respect for characters who think of swimmers as soon-to-be drowned men.
movie_title: Port of Shadows (Le Quai des Brumes) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It knows not to reveal much, to show only what it sees, and yet it manages to suggest very well the severity and urgency of the abyss that always lies beneath the surface.
L!fe Happens wants us to believe its message is one of female independence and empowerment.
All the Skyping, Facebooking, and Googling are, ultimately, tools for animated philosophical conversations about dissemination theory, intellectual affectation, and post-punk identity.
movie_title: Des jeunes gens mödernes (Kids of Töday) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film can feel both refreshingly honest and embarrassingly Lifetime movie-like.
Filmmakers Laura Amelia Guzmán and Israel Cárdenas have crafted a beautiful tale of alienation, solitude, and existential anxiety.
While the doc offers us a story that needs to be told, it does so in very non-Joffrey ways.
Rarely leaves the realm of the obvious and the literal.
An anodyne tale of family-centered acceptance that's neither comical when it wants to be nor touching when it strivers for pathos.
Judging from The Sleeping Beauty, and the previous Bluebeard, the provocations stop with the choice of the material, as the tone and style of these films are jarringly well-behaved.
A lighthearted critique on the fetishized notion of the "non-actor," the ethics (or lack thereof) of the "docudrama," and the packaging of national despair for export.
movie_title: The Woman in the Septic Tank (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While it lends itself to some interesting insight on the politics of non-exclusive, ****-buddy dynamics, its characters are ultimately too one-dimensional and their dialogue too theatrical to sustain an involving cinematic experience.
As hard as he tries, we never truly believe there's a lot at stake for Garner, who seems to cruise through America like a gringo taking a favela tour in Rio.
Oh, the hilarious awkwardness of placing privileged white kids in a place where they don't belong.
The mumblecore dialogue can be annoying, but along with the excellent score, it actually serves this tense haziness well.
Cristián Jiménez's film knows how entangled the will to know is with the will to make love.
The High Life paints a portrait, sometimes tainted by art-house film affectations, of an urban hell in which men are despicable when powerful and depressingly impotent when not.
Suffers from a generic sterility we've come to associate with made-for-TV movies.
Beginners is all about human ambiguity, contradiction, shades of gray, and the inherent imbrication of the joy of having something and the terror of losing it.
The camera has penetrated the fabric of everyday life in unsettling and insidious ways, but not quite enough to mistake the pseudo-documentary-ness of The Magician for recorded reality.
Director Douglas Langway is aware that while bear-ness could be seen as a response to a culture obsessed with gender-conformant and hairless young bodies, it can also be a rather unoriginal one.
There are lengthy sections solely concerned with covering historical ground in which the platonic intimacy between the magistra and the pupil is completely forgotten.
movie_title: Vision: From the Life of Hildegard von Bingen (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Bombay Summer turns Mumbai's chaos into an atmospheric playground for a soap opera-like love triangle to unfold.
A magical realist comedy about the idealization of state-sanctioned heterosexual coupledom.
The only thing perhaps scarier than being surprised by the gay monster is, apparently, mistaking a tranny for a real woman.
Nothing screams hackneyed repurposing like using a Nietzschean citation as preface to very non-Nietzschean drivel.
There's no better cinematic praise than to be evocative of Béla Tarr's tour de force Werckmeister Harmonies.
movie_title: The Temptation of St. Tony (Püha Tõnu kiusamine) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In the film, girlhood is too premature a demand on a child who just wants to, well, play.
The business of cultural erasure through music gains literal status and gruesome consequences in Ngawang Choephel's documentary.
Modus Operandi does fall too in love with its muses to avoid some of its experimental-cum-normative conventions.
Whether this is Vegas or Cape Town, the girl stays home moping while the boys go out and play.
Hiding Divya is so consistently sterile and unabashedly TV-movie-like that when the one great moment in the film comes around, it awakens you like a defibrillator.
Although Hickey's film soon becomes less interested in obscuring its narrative than in unfolding its plot, its intentions remain, refreshingly, never quite clear.

The hedonist possibilities of New York City remain unexplored in Walkaway, whose privileged heterosexual twentysomethings would rather spend their time looking for the perfect partner to take home to Momma.
The People I've Slept With sells marriage as existential panacea and mature denouement.
Leave it to a documentary on the atrocities of a Cambodian genocide to get everything actually right about the way humans store information and retrieve it.
Beautiful Islands teases us with delightful Weerasethakul-esque territory only to abruptly replace that promise of wonder with predictable, sterile documentary filmmaking.
Dirty Hands's witnessing of Choe's "from g to gent" journey is delivered in no linear fashion, perfectly matching the artist's creative process and maniac persona in its editing style.
movie_title: Dirty Hands: The Art & Crimes of David Choe (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Pornography is more in love with the notion that a thriller could come to life in a porn setting than with what is actually interesting and relevant about its subject matter.
Ultimately a necessary genealogy of the "we are what we eat" cliche, a welcome reminder of how eating is the inadvertent daily exercise of politics.
If you were to write an utterly predictable tale of a druggie and then replace "slice of pizza" for every instance of "cocaine" in the script you would get Lbs.
Not much seems to have changed in the world of urban heterosexuals since Hal Salwen's 1995 techno-prophetic classic Denise Calls Up.
Weir is indeed the epitome of the pop star, embodying a bubble-gum histrionics too addicted to any kind of adulation to ever actually take sides.
A beautiful but stiltedly put-together tale of two women who love.
Big River Man is a marketing tool for the hard-drinking, overweight Slovenian swimmer Martin Strel, only it's disguised as a global warming awareness tale of human endurance.
Apart from Gazzara's brilliant, effortless performance, everything is a little cartoonish in Looking for Palladin.
Not that nuance must be a comedy's forte, but most of All You Can Eat unravels as a series of self-conscious fragments and bitchy one-liners.
movie_title: Eating Out: All You Can Eat (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For a film so keen on creating humor off the inaptness of a character's script, Blue Tooth Virgin should have double-checked its own screenwriting chops.
The film is at its finest as a catalogue of Yossi's unspoken ache, less so when it begins to flirt with the clichés of the love story.

The anticlimactic child in Patrik, Age 1.5 isn't as nightmarish as Rosemary's Baby or the man-eating wooden branch-sucking-on-a-pacifier in Jan Svankmajer's Little Otik, but it sets off just as much anxiety.
The film wows us with its objects of study at work that it creates a sensual awareness of our primary relationship with the bees.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Embraces the notion of dancers as characters with histories, more than just beautifully coordinated fleshly parts.
Willets Point is more like an epic student film with the dramaturgical caliber of an STD clinic's grossly underfunded sex-education videos.
Tied to a Chair mostly suffers from a sense of confusion that never reads like bona fide experimentalism, just aimlessness.
For a moment you wonder, or hope, that this will be a film entirely shot in Second Life.
The film's experimental spirit gets washed out by its ultimate surrendering to more conventional, and overrated, narrative imperatives.
Given most people's unfamiliarity with New Zealand idiosyncrasies and politics, much gets lost in translation here.
Lord Byron manages to turn nonsensical gibberish into a captivating soundtrack for the equally fragmented stories of the strangers living in the same home.
This is a plea for self-described indie filmmakers to stop utilizing hyper-polished technique to talk about human misery.
You almost wonder if the whole thing isn't just one big campy joke.
Surprisingly, Cougar Hunting isn't yet another iteration of The Hangover school of misogyny-makes-the-man politics.
In films such as the Italian The First Beautiful Thing, the mother/whore dichotomy collapses in whimsical ways: The mother is the whore.
movie_title: The First Beautiful Thing (La prima cosa bella) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: For a film so bent on celebrating the power of silence, Mysteries of the Jesus Prayer has a whole lot of explanatory talking.
This is the kind of film whose impeccably steady shots and perfectly ordinary televisual aesthetic feel at odds with its subject matter.
Continues the bizarre tradition of documenting how superhero-like white foreigners with commanding accents come to America to revolutionize the way we eat.
A lovely essay film/documentary about the ruthlessness of time and the soothing power of remembrance.
When will American directors understand that it's okay, sometimes even wonderful, for a film to be silent?
While we may have learned to properly code our insecurities in the fabric of everyday life, Kastabi is, ironically, in the business of unabashed honesty.
The film's unabashed willingness to go from bleak topical piece on genital mutilation to guilty-pleasure glamour can be disconcerting.
Dear Lemon Lima is a quirky beauty of a film with its cotton-candy colors, Miranda July-esque sensibility, and its embracing of alienation as a source of creativity.

It's hard to say if the film is aiming for a political critique of the dynamics of the everydayness of suicide bombings in Israel and the country's poor treatment of its immigrant population, or if that's just the way we read anything "Israel."
The film does something quite amazing in allowing the kind of bottled-up emotional dynamic that heterosexual masculinity requires to finally express itself in speech.
Its aesthetic and narrative references feel gratuitous and flat, as Loveless can never match the sensibility of its cinematic muses.
Spread falls victim to the old rules of Hollywood comedies.
Afraid of the dullness of its subject matter, and of being lost in the swarm of patronizing eco-documentaries, Carbon Nation tries really hard to speak to the language of "young people these days."
Unable to recognize how sufficient the visuals themselves are, its music gets increasingly over-dramatic, epic-like.
Blackmail Boys is more interested in the more obvious gay issues such as marriage equality and religious hypocrisy.
The Woodmans isn't out to demonize Francesca's upbringing or to play the blame game for her untimely death.

Surprisingly not macabre, this fictionalized record of self-aggrandizement through self-destruction reminds one of Derek Jarman's Blue in its epistolary delivery and its displacement of meaning to that which is never really shown.
movie_title: The Sound of Insects: Record of a Mummy (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Although the film can feel a little emotionless, director Miao Wang has an emblematic metaphor in her hands.
It might be fair to investigate if "Josh Sternfeld" is a programming language, not a director.
The United States's first couple being a cigar-smoking cowboy and his intellectually challenged wife is one anachronism we could all live without.
The film manages to un-blemish the presumed "abnormal" while asking if it isn't "normality" itself that's in dire need of a checkup.
What does the collector's collecting aim to substitute? What does the collection attempt to replace in the collector?
There's an enormous amount of perverse pleasure to be had here for those who get off on the annihilation of nuance.
Paul Verhoeven's film isn't afraid to inhabit the maddening ambivalence of pleasure.
A raw, sophisticated, and stomach-turning look at what it means to be a young woman in Serbia, what it means to be a woman tout court.
What the film embodies, unfortunately, is the listlessness of its slacker characters.
movie_title: Videofilia (and Other Viral Syndromes) (Videofilia: y otros síndromes virales) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Its fatal mistake is to make up for blindness, instead of embracing it as something other than a liability.
Writer-director Tim Kirkman tries to peg depth of character on the character of Dean instead of having him earn it.
It's difficult to find a reason for the film's existence beyond a spoiled platform for James Franco's ersatz boldness.
Glenn Close's face teems with a flawlessly controlled gravitas that's completely at odds with the film's ordinariness.
From the overtly vibrant colors to the caricaturesque dimensions of the performances, the film's aesthetic promises a great allegorical message that never arrives.
In the logic of the film, for the camera to move at all would feel like a betrayal of its contemplative hunger.
It's when Stephen Dunn dares to inhabit the how and not the what of queerness that the film feels authentic and deliciously strange.
It's an entertaining and unapologetic tale of female risk-taking, filled with clever camerawork, but the characters remain shallow.
Clea DuVall crafts an entire film out of aborted attempts at a revelation that feel completely anodyne.
The film's structure, however stifling, is filled with gorgeous imagery and nuanced symbolism.
The film unapologetically warns us at every turn that fashion is nothing but a business, fueled by naiveté and rape.
The very few instances where stereotypes are challenged are forced and didactically delivered.
Essentially a post-apocalyptic telenovela, it sanitizes the concept of sisterhood, and even womanhood.
Catherine Corsini depicts feminists in lighthearted ways, at once humorously caricatured and sensitively human.
Anne Fontaine's film is an allegory for women's condition more generally, in times of war or peace.
It suggests that when straight men finally offer some kind of reciprocity to gay men, they lose their status as proper objects of desire.
It's more interested in borrowing terminal cancer as a narrative shorthand for intensity than investigating it as a lived experience.
The ingenuity of writer-director Jeremy LaLonde's film ends with its title.
movie_title: How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The drag in the film rejects the U.S.-centric obsession with "realness" and the acrobatics that come with it.
The professional and romantic collaboration of yore is replaced by memories of betrayal, resentment, and bodily decay.
The hygienization of Rio into what at times looks like a soulless Southern California town is so scandalous it feels like a spoof of the Cities of Love series.
movie_title: Rio, I Love You (Rio, Eu Te Amo) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Steen's performance is so mesmerizingly nuanced, her face so overwhelmed, almost twitching with complexity, it's like watching a volcanic explosion inside a small, very delicate flask.
The film enables us to feel the emotional weight of a posthumous letter precisely because we can only imagine its contents.
It's difficult to believe in Ryder's gullibility, if not willingness to be caught in his uncle's strange web of provocations.
Xavier Giannolli consistently glosses every sequence with a stagey kind of humor, albeit at the main character's expense.
It's a refreshing and overdue exposure of the violence that white male privilege breeds and needs to reassert itself.
A film about the ways in which the intellectual pursuit might be a woman's only guarantor against misery, against a complete dependency on others who are sure to abandon them sooner or later.
Bleakness, Arturo Ripstein's film implies, demands different kinds of labor from a man than from a woman.
movie_title: Bleak Street (La calle de la amargura) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: At first, the film's dark humor is amusing, only for it to wear off once an actual plot kicks into motion.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Keith Fulton and Louis Pepe's documentary raises important questions about the limits of pedagogy.
