A summer movie that's made up of parts of some of the best summer movies ever made, Super 8 is neither memorable nor original, but as empty summer blockbusters go, it's a good one.

Far better than one might expect with exciting action and a memorable hero in Caesar. The premise is clever enough to entertain longtime Apes fans while also giving a new generation a great introduction to Planet of the Apes lore.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Wrapped in B-movie trappings from its clichéd script and implausible scenarios to less than thrilling action, the best thing Colombiana has going for it is the lovely Ms. Saldana, who deserves much better than this.

Don't Be Afraid of the Dark might not make viewers forget the television original they grew up with, but has enough under the skin creepiness to entertain those simply looking for a good fright at the movie theatre.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Ill-conceived and ill-timed, this unfunny yuppies' lament couldn't be more insulting to single parents, women, or anyone struggling to make a living. Excuse me while I cry as success ruins the characters' perfect lives.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With noticeable gaps between the telling of its first decade and its second, Pearl Jam Twenty didn't necessarily need to be a feature, but is a really lovely fan letter to a band that's worked hard for the devotion and respect it receives.

Abduction needs two different reviews. For the Lautner fans, this is so the film you've been waiting for. For non-fans, it's full of holes, impossibilities and unintentionally hilarious dialog written by a sixth grader that doesn't get out much.
The Ides of March is a gorgeously shot character study filled with wonderful performances ably structured by Clooney. I only wish all these ingredients had come together for a more compelling cause.

With its excellent cast and emotionally intelligent script, 50/50 isn't necessarily a feel good movie about cancer, but is an exceptional telling of one man's story, mixed with a perfect balance of sympathy and laughs.

Consisting of a few shock pops and queasy effects, The Thing is tired, rote and uninspired, becoming a waiting game to see who gets knocked off next. There's nothing here not seen before, including in its superior 1982 sire.
Flat, charmless and downright boring at times, the not frightening Fright Night will succeed only in making viewers yearn for the far superior original 1985 film.

Its trove of unseen treasures is required viewing for fans, but the majority of time spent on Beatlemania and his spiritual pursuits over nearly four hours leaves viewers with as many questions about George Harrison as when they came in.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Charmingly quirky and cheekily audacious, the story of a young man and the changes caused by his elderly father's late-in-life revelations is crafted with sweetness and originality.
Great voice cast aside, Kung Fu Panda 2 pales beside its snappier sire, but it's entertaining enough and the younger ones in the audience will still eat it up with chopsticks.

Powered by subject Arnel Pineda's charm and humour as well as that excellent classic rock soundtrack, Don't Stop Believin': Everyman's Journey is an inspiring and entertaining fairy tale you really can believe in.

A great date movie; thoroughly romantic and a flight of pure fantasy. What girl wouldn't want to meet the man who would stand up to God and all His angels - sorry, The Chairman and his corporate drones - for the woman he loves?

Equal parts horror, crime drama and exploitation flick, I Saw the Devil takes aspects of all three to create the most outrageous, over the top, disturbing tale of vengeance seen for many a moon. Definitely not for the squeamish.
The lush beauty, poetic storytelling and fresh, vibrant performances from a wonderful cast makes this Jane Eyre one of the most mesmerizing, relevant retells yet seen.

I don't know why this movie exists. A completely unoriginal mash-up of every good alien invasion film there's ever been, resulting in an ugly, uninspired, laughably bad mess that'll give you motion sickness while making your ears bleed.

Not as awesomely awful as Twilight, though director Hardwicke dwells in the same overwrought, teenage fever-dream, while her cast embraces the campiness as if knowing they've signed up for a giant blot on their CVs.

Win Win earns its title as a genuinely warm film that surprises and delights with humour, intelligence and perfect performances from all its cast. The real winner is the audience lucky enough to catch this gem.
Though more attuned to broader humour than the whip-smart wit and cleverness of Pegg and Frost's British comedies, Paul definitely has a loopy charm.

Smart, witty and fun. Perfect summer viewing and a worthy entry to the higher echelons of the Marvel cinematic pantheon. A fine reboot for the franchise and I'd happily look forward to another blast from the X-Men past.

While visually stylish and entertaining, Sucker Punch isn't quite the watershed moment fans of tough broads wielding fists of fury hoped for; instead it might be the priciest bit of softcore porn for otaku and gamers ever produced.
A charming allegory for man - or woman - against machine, Summer Wars is an eye-popping symphony of colour and imagination that leaps from the screen to blow the viewer's mind.

Soul Surfer is a rare film these days, truly heartwarming and inspirational. The performances are wonderful and true and the movie itself is exciting and lovely to look at. It's a perfect family film.

13 Assassins single-handedly revitalises the samurai film, taking it to new heights with incomparable style and excitement. Make all possible haste to see this grand-scale epic on the biggest screen you can find.

With much more to it than its teenage assassin plot, Hanna is a grim fairy tale about a girl's coming-of-age that's also terribly entertaining. Thrilling to both the eye and ear, Hanna stands apart as a cerebral action movie.
Exuberant and full of life, music and colour as the city for which it's named, Rio's combination of a fun script, excellent soundtrack and stunning visuals will delight the entire family.

Everything aboutThor seems afterthought and cast-off, from its cheap-looking production values and dull action to its flat script. It's telling that Chris Hemsworth's shirtless scene is the movie's most special effect.

An exciting mix of the best of Old School kung fu cinema and new technology absolutely worth seeing on big screen. Pity that the film's terrible, tacked-on ending keeps True Legend from being truly legendary.

The series has simply run out of steam. Though better than its predecessor, this chapter owes everything to the Herculean strength of Johnny Depp's charm and the presence of Geoffrey Rush and Ian McShane.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Gorgeous and brilliantly performed as it is, Mildred Pierce's languid pacing and strict adherence to James M. Cain's novel might have been an admirable concept, but doesn't necessarily make for good cinema and possibly even worse television.
Simultaneously mocking and pimping out the 3D gimmick trend, this chapter may be the weakest in the series, but it's still enjoyable with plenty of outrageous laughs.

Stale, unimpressive and possessed of a laughably terrible script that should never have made it past the treatment stage. Even chanting producer James Cameron's name over and over, as in Sanctum's TV spots, can't summon a better movie.

A bit flat and never quite as madcap or wacky as the TV show or early films, The Muppets hits enough right notes to be a pleasing welcome back for longtime fans and a lovely introduction for those deprived of Muppets magic.

Not funny enough to be called a comedy nor remotely frightening or dramatic enough to portray the original TV show's scarier leanings. Dark Shadows has no idea what it wants to be and ends up being nothing.
Beautifully acted and hypnotically staged, Patang is a feast for the senses that doesn't fail to deliver its story of family love and healing with real warmth and heart.

Led by a perfectly cast Charlize Theron devouring the scenery as the evil queen, Snow White and the Huntsman is an entertaining spin on the classic tale, combining great-looking visuals and exciting action.
Charming, poignant and very funny, Paul Williams: Still Alive is a wonderful testament to a truly gifted artist for whom the end of fame was not remotely the end for him.

With its outrageous premise of turning Honest Abe into a slayer of the undead, one would expect to see the president snuffing out vamps in astounding ways. To this end, and as pure, thrill-ride entertainment, the movie certainly delivers.

Brave's wonderful animation, hilarious comedy, excellent voice cast and Pixar's first female lead character is compromised by its lack-of-faith decision to switch mid-plot to a tired, silly device that's unworthy of everything that came before it.

The Dark Knight Rises is by far the worst of the trilogy and surprising in its ineptitude. Lifeless and overlong, one can't make many excuses for this dull, empty, unfocused mess that is a sad end to what was a wonderful ride.

Reveling in the pure, visceral enjoyment of watching stuff blow up on a big screen and rampant destruction where nobody really gets hurt, leave your brain at the door and dig The Expendables 2 for the bombastic blast it is.

Good for more than its share of riotous laughs if a bit disjointed, The Dictator's timely material and Baron Cohen's outrageous, perceptive humour carry the day, with the comedian's fearlessness evident if not as keenly focused as it could be.

Weird, gory and über-violent, Lawless is strangely pleasing in pulpy, thoroughly B-movie way, held to the earth by the thinnest thread of gravity provided by its cast's game and exuberant performances.

Frankenweenie gets back to basics with Burton's trademark oddball style, absurdist charm and ghastly-but-sweet humor and shows the director recharged and remembering why he became a filmmaker. The result is joyous.

While the pure ambition of telling a story in such bravura, non-linear fashion is surely to be applauded, Cloud Atlas is a model of form over function that never quite comes together or compels the viewer to care.
Lovely to look at with thrilling action and a funny script, Rise of the Guardians delivers a sweet and hopeful message about the importance of embracing the magic of childhood

The intelligent storytelling, wise use of access and emotional depth that separates West of Memphis from other documentaries about the murders in Robin Hood Hills, also elevates it to required viewing.

The director pulls off this look at the horrors of slavery with respect for its subject. With Django Unchained, Tarantino, through his incredible, outrageously violent Spaghetti Western Superman fantasy, tells the truth.
The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey is a story stretched too thin; dragged out by drudging slowness and obvious padding that its handful of thrilling action sequences can't improve.

While neither groundbreaking or memorable and burdened by a weird resolution, somehow its pop-up shocks and younger cast's beguiling performances make Mama entertaining enough. After all, mothers can be very scary.

Less the unpredictable zeitgeist fans expect of innovative director Kim Ji-woon and more like the stunt action comedies of the 1970s and 80s The Last Stand is serviceable fun on the visceral level of those films.
Charming, with a lot of laughs and even more heart, Hotel Transylvania is a fun time out at the movies the entire family can enjoy.

Whedon's obvious love for The Avengers' characters, world and fandom makes for a superhero epic that's packed with exciting action, faithful details for comic fans and his signature off-hand wit. It's pure fun and entertainment.

Utterly novel and audacious, The Cabin in the Woods completely rewrites the scary movie as we know it. Intelligent, imaginative and too much fun, it redefines and sets a new standard for the horror movies that will come after it.
Oki's Movie's original and clever premise, charming execution and memorable performances come together beautifully to create a picture that's both captivating and emotional.

Scorsese uses 3D to submerge viewers into a glittering storybook world, but all of Hugo's beauty can't make up for the sidetracking of the tale of the orphaned boy living in the train station in favor of a film preservation PSA.
A stark and stunning portrait of addiction and its resulting damage. Provocative, intelligent and emotionally wrenching, Shame is one of the best films of the year.

A paler retread of the first film is still fun because of the chemistry between Downey Jr. & Law. With a stronger, wittier script and less emphasis on bombast, there's no reason why there shouldn't be one more go.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A magnificent epic that captures the essence and magic of classic movie-making. The heartfelt and emotional War Horse is one of Steven Spielberg's best movies and certainly one of the best films of the year.

A hypnotic cocktail of haunting visuals, strong performances and mesmerizing score. Take the best bits of this captivating new work and cut them into the negligible flaws of the original film and you'd have a perfect story.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Noisy, repetitive and obnoxious, The Adventures of Tintin's sensory overload is somehow blindingly dull. The barrage of onscreen overstimulation will keep kids glued to their seats, but won't make them care about or cherish the characters.

Outstanding performances blend beautifully with a sharp, unsentimental script, stunning cinematography and evocative score to make Norwegian Wood a haunting, mesmerizing symphony of heartache, love, loss and hope.

One of the brightest jewels in Disney's crown, Beauty and the Beast's 3D reissue takes nothing away and makes the film's brilliance even easier to appreciate; the movie is more beautiful and timeless than it ever was.

Hobbled by bad pacing and an anemic script, Haywire should've been a fun popcorn actioner showing off Gina Carano's wonderfully brutal talents, which deserve a far more energetic and inspired vehicle.

Packed with pulse-pounding thrills and genuine spooks, The Grey is a nightmare vision of man versus beast. Neeson's acting chops sell the film's cheesier inclinations while its pacing keeps viewers on the edge of their seats.
In her ninth decade, Carol Channing is the subject of a documentary about her incredible life and devotion to entertainment that is as delightful and effervescent as the bubbly star herself.
The Secret World of Arrietty is an engaging and warm story of a lovely friendship that has enough action and humour to satisfy all ages, and boy, it's awfully pretty.
Canny enough to know how to laugh with its subject, not at it, 21 Jump Street is a lot of fun thanks to a fast-flying, clever script and affectionate regard for its 1980s television roots.
Based on a 1912 Edgar Rice Burroughs novel, John Carter is an overlong, muddled mess of a film that should've waited another hundred years for a good script.
One might predict that Boy, loosely based on the 1980s New Zealand childhood of Taika Waititi, would be funny and offbeat, but the surprise is how refreshingly original, charming and emotional it is.

Maintains the novel's romance to satisfy faithful fans while supplying plenty of action to keep the whole audience entertained. I'll take The Hunger Games over the Twilight series any day, but it's still no Battle Royale.

Far below par for a Tarsem picture, if seen solely on the basis of the family film Mirror Mirror wants so badly to be; the very youngest viewers will be sufficiently entertained by the dwarves' hijinks and silly, slapstick humour.

A boring mess that exists only to milk the fans that made the series a success, but is so unsexy and just plain weird that even the most devoted Twihards stand to be disappointed or grossed out, or possibly, both.
Much more cohesive, fun and thrilling than its predecessor, Wrath of the Titans is a good time at the movies that does the audience the boon of helping it forget the first film ever happened.

A dumb, noisy generic actioner that someone copied and pasted John McClane into to make a buck. Fans of the Die Hard franchise have every right to be insulted as should any movie lover with half a brain.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This is the first time Cheadle has been asked to carry a film, and he plays Rusesabagina as a man of grace and cunning, a somewhat reluctant hero who must use his every resource to save the hundreds of desperate people depending on him.
Nobody gives a more powerful locker room speech than Samuel L. Jackson, while decked out in spiffy suits and flashy neckties.
The big battle scenes are especially disappointing.

It's really a Disney film, like The Incredible Journey, only with people instead of pets.
The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers may well be that true rarity, an almost perfect film.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The script seemed clever, or maybe it was just the way that Hugh Grant delivered his lines.
If Scorsese has been brooding on the subject this long, The Gangs of New York should be a transcendent work.

The mainstream nature of Moskowitz's taste in books undermines his proselytizing for Mossman, whose prose we barely meet in the movie. "I like subplots and twists in stories," he counsels us at one point.
The film's not funny, but it is interesting. That's because this Sandler comedy is more like a Neil LaBute film than a frat boy dorm time waster.
One of the most depressing film's I've ever seen.
The Rundown is cleverly written and thoroughly entertaining.

Colin Farrell as Jim Street may well be one of the great screen performances.

movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

brilliantly constructed, parceling out both its narrative arc and its tidbits of shocking new information with perceptive cunning

Within the limits of Hollywood sterility, CHARLIE'S ANGELS 2: FULL THROTTLE is a fetishist's dream.
The plot has to pause after every meager action scene to express its feelings.
MY LITTLE EYE is the best little "horror" movie I've seen in years.

Maid in Manhattan handles well one of the most difficult components of the romantic comedy, the contrived Trial Separation.
Caton-Jones is one of those directors who seems to lose more personality with each new film he makes.

Beneath the cracked indie surface of Soderbergh's early films there was always a cunning commercial instinct.

I Spy's empty jokes fail to stick to you. It's the olestra of major motion pictures.
Punch-Drunk Love comprises a fairly slight story. The force of the film derives from its interesting, unusual characters.

movie_review_blurb: Should appeal to precocious children... Adults may find it as derivative and simplistic as the steampunk aesthetic to which it's indebted, but for a gateway to more resonant cinema and literature, you could do worse.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Long on portentous symbolism and short on coherent storytelling.
There must be more gravity to the man's life and work than this breezy love letter will admit.

What constitutes self-determination and what responsibility humans have toward other sentient beings can't be answered by a single film, but this is nevertheless a valuable contribution to an ongoing and still-shifting conversation.

While some of the plot points in this Mexican drama strain logic, there's an undeniable emotional truth to every step the woman takes; the icy, formal cinematography assists by accentuating her helplessness against a faceless bureaucracy.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Marcie Begleiter directed this warm documentary about the short, extraordinary life of the title artist, who died at age 34 of a brain tumor.
I haven't read the John le Carré novel that inspired this incoherent mess, but I have to imagine the old spymaster connected the dots better than they are here.
Minervini has captured a segment of American society too often ignored and mocked, but sometimes he's overtaken by the urge to romanticize decrepitude.

Koreeda allows the action to unfold gradually, and plum wine isn't the only food metaphor enriching his tale. Each meal seems like an invitation for the sisters to learn more about each other or to be reminded-for good or ill-of their parents.
Framed by a memorial concert at San Quentin, where the noted bebop player was incarcerated for many years, this 2014 documentary by N.C. Heikin lays bare the contradictions of his creative life.
movie_title: Sound of Redemption: The Frank Morgan Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Much of Jason Bourne consists of grim action set pieces interspersed with long sequences of people sitting in front of computer screens. Somehow the movie is simultaneously frenetic and static, going nowhere really, really fast.
Digital photography, with its limited ability to capture rapid movement, renders the close combat choppy and disorienting, and none of the kills is especially memorable.
Zoe Kazan provides the only compelling moments... yet playing the normal one among such a group of narcissists is a thankless task.

The extravagant expense of this Steven Spielberg production is evident in every frame, but no amount of money or technical trickery can make up for a story lacking any dramatic tension or a sympathetic protagonist.
Check your sense of reality at the door and enjoy the lavish costumes, nonstop action and well-rendered sets.
There is enough depth of drama to warrant a (short) TV series, but not a film.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Writer/director Joe Cornish has young wannabe gangstas battling aliens in a hilarious, action-packed combination of monster movie and underclass teenage story. Trust!
With the closing credits, memory erasure is guaranteed.
Dreamworks have outdone themselves with the glorious 3D rendering in Madagascar 3, especially with the circus scenes, accompanied by the modern dance-pop soundtrack.
Not much of a drift away from what has been done before, Ice Age 4 remains on its initial solid ground.
The epilogue leaves you feeling hollow and empty, but as a less-than-satisfying film concludes, you may also realise that this is entirely the point.
movie_title: A Film with Me in It (2008)

movie_review_blurb: West is an impeccable craftsman, his storytelling chops as fatless and near-faultless as ever.
Whatever you think is going to happen to these fellas, does.

A series of elaborate action setpieces, most of which are stupid and numbly staged... do little to distract from the relentlessly workmanlike nature of the film's bread-and-butter man-on-man tests of endurance.
All of this Eggers frames with a subconscious knack for creating tension within each shot, rarely relying on jump scares or gore, instead mounting suspense through one masterful edit after another.
Martyrs is a film that wants you to believe it doesn't revel in its own depravity, but there's little evidence it has anything else on its mind.
All sound and fury, signifying nothing -- just clichés begetting clichés.

If Bone Tomahawk is a neo-cannibal-western-thriller-romance, then it's always fun to watch a filmmaker pull off the film he's probably always wanted to make. Which Zahler seems to do his first go-round.
Masquerading as a hip-hop martial arts musical, Tokyo Tribe is mostly just a puerile male fantasy come to hypercolor life.
Full of sadness and stubbornness and a kind of cosmic anger, it seeks abandon through destruction, starting with humanity's first and best crutch: language.
First-time filmmaker Marah Strauch spent years crafting something of a perfect eulogy to Carl Boenish -- and her dedication to investigating his outsized life is palpable.
The Connection plods along, unable to find its pace, stuck somewhere in the middle of the straightest line between the movie it madly wants to be, and the movie it just sort of is.

Director Teddy Chan knows his way around a brutal fight scene for sure, and he makes it clear from even the film's first moments that his return to directing after five years will be totally in thrall to the filmmaking dynasties that raised him.
In his latest feature, the breathtaking Jauja, Argentinian director Lisandro Alonso demonstrates that he is the rare filmmaker who trusts his audience enough to winnow his films down to the bone.
It Follows is itself a film that thrives in the borders, not so much about the horror that leaps out in front of you, but the deeper anxiety that waits at the verge of consciousness.

Statham, in turn, is an aloof, drowsy shell of a leading man, the full embodiment of a 100-minute sad grimace. He seems just as bored as the audience must be. He is, once again, so much better than this.

Goodnight Mommy still seems to set its sights on more psychological thriller territory, but by the time that finale (that twist) unveils its disturbing details, the strictures of genre hardly matter in light of the darkness at the film's heart.
If the film is about grief, then the film must act as grief acts. Unmoored and aimless, Jackie acts like a bad dream.

Shults's film is many things-heart-wrenching, paced to perfection, a masterclass in visual storytelling and genuinely terrifying-but that nothing about it feels beyond the grasp of what Shults wants it to be, of what he knows it can be.
Every performance here is deeply felt and quietly heartbreaking-crafting Land of Mine into a measured, often beautiful meditation on moral relevance.
Black Panther might be the first MCU film that could claim to most clearly be an expression of a particular director's voice.
Gorgeous and gross in equal measure, propelled by the sense that anything could happen, Like Me is a visual feast.

Blair and Cage operate as if not being fully committed to their roles isn't a choice, plus a late cameo care of Lance Henriksen brings the well-needed pain. And yet, none of it ever escalates past a baseline of digestible insanity.
At no point are we invited to care about any of these people.
Which is why Darkest Hour transcends its biopic trappings to work, almost despite itself. It's a beautiful thing, Wright's film.
Daddy's Home 2 operates without memory or shame.
This vision is Rat Film, Anthony's brilliant docu-essay chronicling Baltimore's city planning and resultant systemic segregation as a microcosm of the still-failing American Urban Experiment.
Justice League isn't funny, because it still believes it has something important to show us. It doesn't.
Who is this movie for? The only answer is the saddest, because it's just another question: This movie is for the Mulleavys-can anyone else watch this and think otherwise?
It's only in Dayveon's final act that plot contrivances begin to wander away from Abbasi's carefully calibrated realism.
If the South actually were able to invade Hollywood, whoever was involved in this movie would probably have it coming.

It's more sensation than story --more impressionistic than thematic. As an accomplishment alone, it should be held as a landmark... but as a narrative rather than as an object to admire, it struggles to have anything salient to say.
Herzog and co. seem totally tone deaf to how gross all of it is, which is much grosser than Gael García Bernal screaming about diarrhea, which is actually pretty funny.

Williams is a gifted director who only has better films in front of him; he appears to be a guy with a concise vision making exactly what he wants to make. Which might be why The Human Surge can't quite connect: Williams only made this for himself.
movie_title: The Human Surge (El auge del humano) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Barras's most impressive feat-besides keeping the film under 70 minutes-is how effortlessly he gives the film to Zucchini, never once letting the corruption of the adult world stain My Life as a Zucchini's lively hues and livelier magnanimity.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Blade Runner 2049, then, is undoubtedly the most gorgeous thing to come out of a major studio in some time.
As an heir apparent to a Louis Leterrier spectacle, it hasn't an extremely high bar to reach, and yet it still turns the process into a boring bodge job.
Tim Miller, whose background is in VFX houses and animated segments from the likes of Thor: The Dark World, adheres to stock-standard, CG-assisted thrills from the word go.
Room's omissions are the more sinister kind that the Oscars have long been guilty of ... reducing complicated development and trauma to a sententious paste.
Zobel's greatest ally is returning editor Jane Rizzo, who shows remarkable control in skipping through the linear timeline.
As sublime as 3D character animation gets.
Zootopia, like its protagonist, walks blissfully into a jungle of discourse it has precious little chance of surviving.
More interested in appeasing an older audience that already treats the condition as a wondrous curiosity, rather than moving them even an inch outside their comfort zone.
With action that varies between middling and tedious, the only winner in Hemsworth holding a harpoon aloft and starving for this Behind-the-Music tale is Hemsworth himself.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film drowns its ideological responsibility out with enough gunplay and gravitas to invite the wrong kind of laughter.
movie_title: Library Wars: The Last Mission (Toshokan sensô: The Last Mission) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: No part of al-Shabab's fatal zeal is romanticised by directors Nasib Farah and Søren Steen Jespersen.
movie_title: Krigerne fra nord (Warriors from the North) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Every conceivable thing is done to replicate the feeling of navigating the game short of placing a controller in our hands.
It all feels shudderingly hollow; a stack of briefs filled to a fault by a pair of journeyman directors.
As War on Everyone elbows its way through clichés to a blood-soaked finale, it reveals an unassailable penchant for morbid absurdity that is totally McDonagh's own.
The ensuing black comedy, violence and commentary are about as elucidating as a left-wing Facebook meme.
It's a traditional fantasy journey powered in its own right by a sense of the unknowable and a star turn from Benedict Cumberbatch.
Putting Fantastic Four's box office and production woes aside leaves nothing more than a malformed curio.
The action is what makes the movie. Smith and Lawrence's witty comebacks and petty quarrels are still funny though they'll never be as fresh.
It's never boring, but it also never gets beyond averagely good.
An extremely entertaining watch, if not a wholly empathetic experience.
The Transformers films should be looking to this for inspiration in how to make such a movie so rad.
Be afraid. Be very afraid.
Slightly more watchable than the chore I anticipated.
A shamelessly hagiographic chronicling of the final months of the Great Emancipator's life.
The recent influx of Scandanavian thrillers and murder mysteries gets an amusingly grimy entry.
There's nothing groundbreaking going on here, and that's part of the charm. It's just a well-told story of a man doing what's right.
It's an embarrassment for all involved.
This film stands ably on its own, offering up generous piles of large scale fantasy underscored by genuine emotional heft and boundary-pushing visuals.
Contains the kind of conventions that are fun to revisit with a skilled director and a game cast.
It's not spectacular, but it is good enough to see on the big screen.
It's just a touch... predictable. But so are many good movies.
An impossible-to-dislike burst of positive energy brimming with winsome performances.
A down-and-dirty hardcore action fest with style and thrills to burn.
One of the most purely pleasurable 'grown-up' films I've seen this year.
A one of a kind movie from one of the most exciting new directors around, equal parts hilarious; disturbing and wonderful.
Has more bloody on-screen deaths than any action film in recent memory.
Lone Survivor is a proficiently-made film with plenty to enjoy, but truly embracing it is difficult outside of an American context.
The Rock looks like a superhero, and that undermines this film's multi-pronged approach to making a more 'grounded' Dwayne Johnson vehicle.
The auto carnage lacks flair or creativity.
A breezy watch with a higher laugh rate that most comedies released in the cinemas these days.
The bold and bloody visual style remains reasonably compelling and the seafaring battle sequences mark the film apart from the original.
There may be plenty of studio comedies that are better than this film, but there are more that are worse.
Once you begin to feel its rhythms, the film's mastery is undeniable.
Although it pretty much just revels in its own crapulence, I enjoyed Grudge Match.
You can sense the resonance the tropes may have had on the page, but on film they stumble forth feeling clichéd and tired.
There's an 'American' quality to its social conscience that I cannot recall perceiving in any other recent film.
Writer/director Stuart Blumberg got me to care about the characters and their fate to a degree all too rare in medium-sized American dramas.
A perfectly enjoyable exercise in superheroics, and much more fun to watch than 'Man of Steel'.
The best film of its kind since Touching The Void.
Watts is let down by the Mills & Boon-level script, and I couldn't stop wondering how the originally-cast (and more age-appropriate) Jessica Chastain might've done in the role.
An entertaining spin on macho theatrics with amusing lead performances and a bizarre true story to tell. Definitely worth the effort.
Doesn't quite build on the dazzling potential of District 9, but it doesn't fail the previous film either.
The Conjuring feels like someone chucked Poltergeist, Paranormal Activity, The Orphanage, Insidious and especially The Amityville Horror into a blender, then added a bit with a doll.
Superman's grand, mythic nature is both his greatest strength as a character and his fatal weakness. Man of Steel can't quite overcome this, but it's a heck of a lot of fun watching it try.
While it never stops calling attention to itself, it's still a wonder to behold.
Superhero movies just don't get better than this.
The most Wes Anderson-ish film Wes Anderson has ever made, 'Moonrise Kingdom' won't convert any naysayers to the cause, but fans of his work will have a ball.
Baltasar Kormákur does a respectable job of maintaining the tension throughout Contraband
They could've called it Ron Burgundy Runs For Congress.

...probably a little too generic (and long) to win over a grown-up audience rendered blasé about movie robots by the Transformers movies, but kids should respond well to its finely calibrated wish-fulfilment story.
...had me holding my hands over my eyes for the first time since Natalie Portman did horrible things to her cuticles in Black Swan.
A guaranteed good time, be you lady or gentleman.
Less of a stoner comedy than the title and marketing suggested, but still impressively committed to being as offensive as possible, I found myself appreciating the depths this was willing to plumb.
I was utterly enthralled from the first frame to the last.
The alarmingly plastic surgery-ified Cher, with her face looking like a condom stretched over a beach umbrella, gives a performance here as the club owner that's not so much 'still' as 'immobile'.
A must-see for anyone with even the slightest interest in how the planet is run.
A firecracker up the backside of the bloated modern action movie...
A solid and occasionally genuinely freaky little effort.
I was tested by Killers' gaping lack of a single distinguishing characteristic.
Determining the exact level of artifice never stops being distracting, and the emotional climax is far from earned.

It's not hard to get excited about the cinematic potential of a series of short stories about romance set in the most famous city in the world... but the vignettes themselves veer wildly between light charm and severe pretension.
Get out and see this magnificent thriller before the American remake (starring Russell Crowe, planned for release later this year) steals its thunder.
This gorgeous and affecting drama makes a strong case for the simple restorative power of communication.
Despite the surfeit of clichés and apparent lack of any original thought in this hopelessly contrived rom-com, it remains a reasonably amiable exercise.
I died a little bit inside.
Evokes the sensation of witnessing a couple who think everything the other person does is superlatively amusing, but are insufferable to all around them.
An interest in modern dance isn't necessary to enjoy the film.
The alien environment makes Viva Riva! a fascinating watch.
Starts of slow but builds gradually into a captivating tale of escalating mania.
About as obvious and predictable a French comedy as you could imagine. I loved it.
Pattinson fails to step up and command this film with his performance, and never settles on anything definitive for his character.
A collection of pop moments already explored extensively.
I wish more films had this level of ambition, along with the artistry to execute it.
...may feel a little bit generic when you remove the Scandinavian origins but you could do a lot worse for an evening's entertainment.
Some half-way decent character comedy props up this otherwise pretty frivolous outing that marks burgeoning star Jay Baruchel's first cinematic leading role.
...Tim Burton's best film since 2003's Big Fish.
...an admirably slick production...
Peter Berg doesn't inject Battleship with much personality, but he shoots the action here with a clarity I appreciated.
This movie rules.
The best comedy to be released so far this year.
Sets a high standard for the event movies to follow.
Many of the elements are familiar, but the setting, the actors and the director's confident style set them apart.
If you're proudly in touch with your inner idiot, you may find yourself pumping your fist.
This is a nifty, watchable piece of wish-fulfilment entertainment with more than a couple of standout moments.
This is one of the best contemporary dramas to come along in years.
Whilst this remains reasonably captivating for its first hour, it kinda runs out of steam after that...
Shows little interest in the reality-bending ambiguities of the original, and is content to tell a pretty straight-forward (read: dull) spy story.
There may be no faulting Aronofsky's ambition, but the finished product is another story altogether.
Michael, Morgan and Alan roll out more than enough of the old magic to keep the proceedings enjoyable.
Never once elicits a genuine laugh or even the slightest amount of empowerment.
Christopher Nolan affirms his status as contemporary cinema's boldest blockbuster director with this intensely immersive and relentlessly stirring chronicle of the famous World War II evacuation.
Diverting by only the lowest of standards, this film is saved from one-star indignity by mere virtue of its production value. But make no mistake -- this is a bad movie.
A thoughtful, nimble argument for a more character-focused superhero movie, Spider-Man: Homecoming demonstrates what can be gained when the fate of the planet isn't at stake.

The proceedings are also buoyed by such franchise mainstays as the endearing sweetness of Gru's relationship with his three adopted daughters and the mildly European aesthetic that helps distinguish these films from their peers.
Although diverting in the moment, the spatial geography of the epic action is poorly sustained, which undercuts the tension, and once again makes you wonder how something so big can feel so small.
Wonder Woman is a great movie by any measure, but it's at its best when it embraces and embodies the universe-defying potential inside the heart of every little girl.
Although perhaps not for all audiences, John Wick: Chapter 2 is everything an action fan could wish for.
It may be little too concerned with dishing out twist after predictable twist, plot-wise, but that ultimately doesn't really matter when a film looks and feels this cool.
If nothing else, this is a heck of a lot more entertaining than the staid 2004 King Arthur film starring Clive Owen.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Get out and see this rip-snorting thrill-fest and ensure more mid-sized horrors get a cinematic run in Kiwi theatres.
The nostalgia on display, as fun as it often is, somewhat overshadows the storytelling.
Very young audience members should enjoy the surfeit of fart and bum jokes, but unless you're a seriously clucky grown-up, guardians will struggle to find much to carry them through.
Although the end result may feel a touch inconsequential, there's a huge amount of fun to be found in this sunny, nimble and witty film.
Movies about giant monsters don't live or die on "larger points" and Kong: Skull Island remains a consistently entertaining hoot throughout.
A lot more enjoyable than the 2005 sequel, but never comes close to scaling the heights of Verbinski's film.
It's perfunctory, competent, but lacking in dazzle or flair. For franchise completists only.
At it's best is more reminiscent of forgotten '80s comedies like Club Paradise (1986) or Hot Pursuit (1987).
The audience for this film already knows who it is. It won't convert anyone not already committed to the cause...
I would usually be more than ready to endorse a film that presented little more than a surfeit of eye-popping visuals, but liking a movie shouldn't require this much effort.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's not the most dazzling documentary, but the urgency of the issue is well-illustrated, and the power is placed firmly in the hands of the audience by the end.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For all its frivolity, fans should be more than satisfied with this final run around the track.
There is fun to be had here. As long as you do your best not to think about it too hard.
Any cynicism about Wonder's intentions is easily squashed by its emotionally forthright execution. You're guaranteed to leave the theatre with a strong belief in the power of kindness.
This all plays out like it was designed for 9-year-olds, who'll likely eat it up.
Ultimately, what in theory could've been the superhero epic to end all superhero epics ends up having all the impact of an average episode of a live-action Justice League TV show.
Highly recommended but be advised: from the opening shot, this is a extremely distressing watch.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The subject matter becomes a vehicle for salient observations about social ambition, the version of ourselves we choose to present to others, and the nature of friendship.

There's a surfeit of Stephen King references that are fun to identify, and more than one impactful set-piece, but it's clear that the mythic qualities of this story have been lost in the journey to the big screen.
I was hoping for something special here.
Undemanding yet not unrewarding, Home Again is an entertaining diversion that is clear about its intentions and easily fulfils them.
Although perhaps a tough-sell on paper, Waru stands a sturdy testament to the way film can generate resonant art from difficult subject matter. All New Zealanders should see it.
Star Wars fans old and new are guaranteed to have an absolute blast.
A beautiful film with a cosmic power that creeps up on you, A Ghost Story is one of the most interesting American films of the year.
A breezy, funny film about serious subject matter, Battle of the Sexes benefits from some winning lead performances and the admirably light touch...
Although this is clearly attempting to emulate The Lego Movie with its knowing tone, it's remains a nakedly hollow exercise all throughout. Less fun than a break-up text.
Even if this new It's ambitions to be Stand By Me with horror aren't ever quite properly fulfilled, it stands as a valiant pursuit of that ideal.
This is a heartfelt and colourful antidote to popcorn-cinema fatigue.
Isn't a life changer, but it's an effective true-life thriller with an authentic weightiness to what's on screen.
A missed opportunity for sure.
A nasty little addition to the minor 2016 horror boom, Don't Breathe tops up its surfeit of straight-forward jump scares with an impressively disgusting third-act reveal.
A hearty reminder of how much more effective a film like this can be when you actually care about the characters.
Stay far away if romantic movies bother you. For everyone else, this very much delivers on its earnest intentions.
The first film was impossible to take seriously and that is still the case for the sequel. But it's less of a chore.
The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel was often referred to as 'The Avengers for pensioners'. Which I suppose would make this follow-up 'Age of Ultron for pensioners'.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A relatively old school private eye drama that maintains attention without leaving a lasting impression.
Now that I've seen the late-arriving sequel, I can't for the life of me work out why I ever thought it would be a good idea.
Before I Go to Sleep is the kind of casually effective thriller we see too little of these days.
I laughed at least three times.
Like some of his crummier recent output, this feels like an old script Allen found in a drawer somewhere.
An overly familiar collage of bombastic bewilderment.
An instant classic ready for enduring cult success.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: McFarlane's courting of Charlize Theron occasionally plays with the gag-inducing coyness of a Katherine Heigl rom-com.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Veers between interesting and insipid for much of its running time.
If I wasn't watching this in a theatre, I might've presumed I got sent the film on VHS after responding to a late-night infomercial.
Funny, forgettable froth.
A far cry from the best the medium has to offer, but there are more proper laughs than usual here...
If you go in viewing this as a kind-of cinematic open mic night, you may just have a rockin' time.
There is more than enough genuine wonder in Tomorrowland to justify your attention. Unless you're a cynical jerk.
Chef very much deserves to join Big Night and Dinner Rush in the canon of great American food movies.
It's impossible not to pump your fist.
Often unnerving, and always interesting, but rarely as lyrical as the film seems to be aiming for.
Things simply gel in this film in a way we always hoped they would in this new Star Trek universe.
It delivers more than its fair share of jump scares and knows when to bail out.
If we can somehow separate the film from the expectations implied by the genre-defining LOTR the unique pleasures of Warcraft: The Beginning become a little easier to embrace.
I was never bored watching Money Monster, but I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being talked down to.
A more enjoyable and cohesive film than its ephemeral predecessor. Which isn't saying a huge amount, but still...
Makes concessions to nothing and nobody - it is about as pure an expression of the writer/director's sensibilities as you could ask for.
You'll have forgotten the whole thing by the time you reach the parking lot.
Although the experience may be slightly less suspenseful for viewers of the earlier film, The Walk is worth seeing alone for its mounting of the climactic feat.
An enjoyable watch.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Gives generic action movies a bad name.

[Brie Larson's] phenomenal, and very much deserving of the Oscar, but Jacob Tremblay's performance as her son Jack is so stunning, he more or less asserts his own status as the film's actual protagonist.
All respect to Leo, but Fassbender deserves an award just for getting through the dialogue here alone.
There is a weighty tactility and sense of scale in the split-oil tanker scenes that wasn't present in either The Perfect Storm or Titanic.
A leisurely, articulate and strangely funny descent into hell.
Iñárritu dives deep into the savagery of the setting and characters, exploring the insanity from all angles while maintaining a remarkably steady directorial hand.
Handsomely mounted (the muted '50s technicolour aesthetic is particularly appealing) and populated by subtle performances...
Suffers greatly for the over-familiarity of its generic YA dystopian aspirations.

Arthur and Merlin is a triumph of British independent filmmaking and a modern fantasy staple. Van Belle has conjured an atmospheric adventure, full of quirky campiness, rollicking good humour and, most importantly, fun.
... it doesn't seem interested in engaging with the complex social and political issues that should really saturate it.
... with a cast and crew as strong as this, Godzilla should have been more than a disposable Hollywood blockbuster.
A very funny, resonant and, most importantly, self-aware film that allows a grade-A performer to show off his deadpan chops.
Arrival is at its best early on, when everything is-figuratively speaking-up in the air.
McDonald doesn't want you to have fun, he wants you to be about as uncomfortable as Dora is and, for the most part, he succeeds.
For most of its running time Vol. 2 feels low stakes, but boy is that a welcome change.
Though Mayhem is far from perfectly executed, the executions in it are damn near perfect.
An acutely observed portrait of the lives of first and second generation Chinese immigrants, subjects who otherwise don't see much in the way of Hollywood limelight.
It's a testament to the accomplished cast that this works; so much tension and emotion is wrought from their subtle glances and small talk.
It is a generic origin story but it's well executed, building energy and excitement in a way that even the most celebrated Marvel films struggle to match.
Made with an unrelenting enthusiasm that steps beyond its occasionally patchy comedy, They Came Together is smart, subversive and really quite funny.
Its screenplay may clunk, and its logic may be questionable even by the standards of comic book movies, but The Amazing Spider-Man 2 remains a rather fun bit of cinematic overkill.
While its pace meanders, Stranger by the Lake proves to be an engrossing and darkly humorous watch.
Ambition should never be chided, but 52 Tuesdays spends most of its runtime trying to shout before it can speak.
Concussion is well acted, well written and genuinely entertaining, but I just wish that it had rung a little less hollow.
It may look rather serious, but underneath The Machine's shiny and po-faced exterior is an enjoyable, silly little B-movie.
Valentine Road is an engrossing, multifaceted tale of pain and bigotry, as told by a moron.
Better Living Through Chemistry seems all too happy to paddle around in the shallow end and ape much more significant works, but I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy it.
The subject matter is powerful, and the performances are wonderful - in a world of big and showy dramatism, Lilting gets its point across without feeling the need to shout about it.
Starred Up is draining, brutal and absolutely unforgettable. Hands down, this is one of 2014's must-see movies.
Salvo is the cinematic equivalent of using a really big font to cover up the fact that your college dissertation is 50 words long.
Slow-paced and brooding, A Most Wanted Man won't be to everyone's tastes, but it's a must see for Le Carré fans.
You can dress it up all you want, but there's no hiding the fact that Cuban Fury is as bland as they come.
As much as I wanted to enjoy it, Young Ones' over-stretched plot and stunted script leaves it feeling like an art-house short that was given too much money.
I Origins is a semi-bizarre mix of sci-fi, parable and romantic drama that, while frequently engaging, never really holds together.
The Skeleton Twins is a wonderful comedy-drama made with heart and filled with plenty of broken ones.
Knowingly melodramatic, wonderfully cheesy and all-out bonkers, The Guest is an absolute blast from beginning to end.
The entire cast is impressive, but unfortunately, Whiplash rarely raises itself above amiably decent.
My thoughts on The Hunger Games: Catching Fire can be summed up as such: Bigger? Yes. Better? Not really. Bonkers? Absolutely.
Though it hints at so much promise, The Counselor never quite hits you in the way you would hope. The pieces may be there, but it never finds the panache to put them all together.
Undoubtedly the director's latest fever-dream of style, Gilliam's The Zero Theorem never quite takes the time to get its substance together.
It takes a specific kind of person to thoroughly enjoy Hits, and I - somewhat worryingly - am one of them.
Slow, low-key and often beautifully observed, Blue Is the Warmest Colour won't blow your mind, but it will charm your socks off.
Keira Knightley impresses, but Laggies' amiable charm is absolutely wrecked in a final third that's short on laughs and packed with clichés.
Calvary treads worryingly close to the theater work of John Michael McDonagh's younger sibling, and never quite lives up to such lofty standards.
For the over-sensitive kid in all of us, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is something truly earnest, truly heartfelt and truly beautiful.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Voices is a complete and utter mess - that said, I'm glad that it exists. It would take a stickler to begrudge the world of cinema something this odd
Adore is nothing more than a hateful excuse for a piece of cinema. Avoid it at all costs.
Half of a good film and half of not a very good film, Stockholm, Pennsylvania's mid-runtime fall from grace almost needs to be seen to be believed.
Over-egged, underwritten and less scary than a barrel of inherently friendly puppies, The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death fails in just about every way a horror film can.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The cinematic equivalent of someone furiously clearing slightly moldering leftovers from their fridge, The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies leaves its audience departing Middle Earth for the last time with an awful taste in the mouth.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Both a grower and a shower, You and the Night's ropy beginnings give way to a trippy, smart and distinctly original delight.
movie_title: You and the Night (Les rencontres d'après minuit) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Bateman charms, Wilde pouts, and nothing much else happens in The Longest Week's convoluted analysis of aimless privilege.
A fascinating larger-than-life portrait of its larger-than-life subject, I Am Divine is a beguiling blend of poignancy, humor and glorious excess.
As poetic and downright weird as the snake-hipped icon at its center, 20,000 Days On Earth is a messy and endlessly fascinating look at one of music's great wild men.

A promising cast, a zany concept and a lead eager to cast off her type-cast shackles don't add up to much in Life of Crime, as it ultimately turns out to be a caper-farce that's chronically short of panache.
Mutual Friends isn't awful by any means, but that doesn't make it any good.
Two Days, One Night gets its point across in the first 30 minutes, only to treat you to another hour of bittersweet nothings.
Boyhood is an oversized and sprawling smorgasbord of a movie, blending the beautiful with the irritating in a rich and messy tapestry of growing pains and pubescent grumbling.
Despite a strong start, The Young and Prodigious T.S. Spivet eventually fizzles out and ends up as a wholly mediocre film.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Foibles be damned, Edge of Tomorrow is mindless fun of the highest order.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Overlong and comedically uneven, A Million Ways to Die in the West spends far too much time treading water and nowhere near enough time being funny.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It may spend more time paying homage to classics than finding its own voice, but Wolf picks and chooses its influences very well indeed.
Ida is a gorgeous and humble tale of stiff upper lips and scars that refuse to heal, where every frame is imbued with melancholic beauty and a quiet grace.
Dancing between the fun and the all-out ridiculous with surprisingly nimble feet, X-Men: Days of Future Past is an absolute blast.
Filth doesn't as much stare into the Abyss as eyeball it from across the room before sprinting over and licking it.
Watching The Angriest Man in Brooklyn is about as much fun as repeatedly punching yourself in the face.
A film that joyously revels in blurred lines, Venus in Furs sees Polanski return to his bold and fiercely original best.
In a world despicably over-saturated with British period dramas, Belle is a really rather pleasant surprise.
Despite Banks' swashbuckling performance, Walk of Shame is about as mediocre as they come.
Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter is a wonderful little film that dares to dream, and dares you to dream with it.
Whilst undeniably pretty, As I Lay Dying never amounts to the kind of significance its source material, cast and portentous stylings would imply.
